biogHists.text:
Maybee was a history professor at CMU. The Clarke Historical Library has several of his publications and his papers. The Advisory Committee developed plans for major events, publications, re-dedications of campus buildings, presentations, and a historical marker for CMU's 75th Anniversary. The Awards Screening Committee reviewed nominations of people who had contributed significantly in some way to CMU, selected honorees, and organized a presentation ceremony and plaque for each honoree. The Clarke also has the papers of Senator Robert P. Griffin.

From the description of 75th Anniversary Collection, 1893-1972. (Clarke Historical Library). WorldCat record id: 44522492

Central Michigan University (CMU) held a centennial anniversary celebration in 1992. For early historical records, see the collections of the CMU College of Education and Human Services. Engler served as Gov. of Mich., 1991-2002; Mich. Senator, 1979-1990, and in the Mich. House of Reps., 1970-1978. McBryde served as the 99th Dist. Rep., 1990-1998. He graduated from CMU in 1972. Camp served a term as a Mich. Rep. before being elected as a U.S. Congressman from Mich.'s 4th District in 1990. He was re-elected in 2000. Smith served as Mount Pleasant (Mich.)'s mayor in 1992 and 1996. (Information from Mich. Manual, government websites, and Mount Pleasant city hall.).

From the description of Centennial anniversary collection, 1992. (Clarke Historical Library). WorldCat record id: 51180567

CMU was called Central State Teachers College from 1927 through 1941.

From the description of Miscellaneous financial collection, 1925,2003. (Clarke Historical Library). WorldCat record id: 62364726

In this time period, there was no Registrar's office at what was then Central State Normal School. These records were probably kept by the two secretaries for the college.

From the description of Classification registers, 1904,1910. (Clarke Historical Library). WorldCat record id: 46674744

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:84896983</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Berriman, Stan.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1884,2003.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1884-2003 (Scattered), and undated, consists mainly of scrapbooks, typed notes, typed 3"x4" and 4"x8" notecards, reel-to-reel tapes, a 16 mm film, and color slides. The vast majority of the collection, particularly the note cards and slides, document Michigan historic markers, historic sites, events, counties, townships, Chippewa Indians, and school trips that Berriman took his history classes on to the Upper Peninsula, the Straits area, and Grayling (Mich.). Also included are the 1884 and 1885 tax assessor's assessment books for Jerome Township (Midland County). Midland County history is well documented in the collection. Stan also compiled lists of Michigan reference souces, information about historic markers by county, and information about county, township, city, and village histories which are on the notecards. A plumber's account book for M. A. Co. Pipe Shop, 1912-1914, completes the collection. A few items in the collection are quite acidic and brittle and should be used with care by researchers. Other items have a slightly musty odor, and researchers with asthma or allergies may wish to be careful while using the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Collection, 1884,2003.
resource.abstract: The collection, 1884-2003 (Scattered), and undated, consists mainly of scrapbooks, typed notes, typed 3"x4" and 4"x8" notecards, reel-to-reel tapes, a 16 mm film, and color slides. The vast majority of the collection, particularly the note cards and slides, document Michigan historic markers, historic sites, events, counties, townships, Chippewa Indians, and school trips that Berriman took his history classes on to the Upper Peninsula, the Straits area, and Grayling (Mich.). Also included are the 1884 and 1885 tax assessor's assessment books for Jerome Township (Midland County). Midland County history is well documented in the collection. Stan also compiled lists of Michigan reference souces, information about historic markers by county, and information about county, township, city, and village histories which are on the notecards. A plumber's account book for M. A. Co. Pipe Shop, 1912-1914, completes the collection. A few items in the collection are quite acidic and brittle and should be used with care by researchers. Other items have a slightly musty odor, and researchers with asthma or allergies may wish to be careful while using the collection.
resource.extent: Approx. 4 cubic ft. (in 9 boxes, 2 folders, 2 Ov. v.) : ill.
resource.displayEntry: Berriman, Stan. Collection, 1884,2003.

resourceRelations.content: Berriman, Stan. Collection, 1884,2003.

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Business records, 1991-1997.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection consists of Schock's recording business correspondence, documenting arrangements and ideas for recorded interviews, commercials, dance recitals, and musical recordings, mostly of Mount Pleasant people, businesses, schools, and organizations, and Central Michigan University faculty and students musical productions, 1991-1997, and undated. Included are paper business correspondence, notes, drafts of scripts, as well as informational materials about the businesses and organizations (1 cubic ft.), and the master and draft cassette recordings (in 6 cassette storage boxes). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>Papers, 1988-1990 and 2006, consist mainly of materials Professor Rose submitted to the Department of Teacher Education & Professional Development (TEPD) at Central Michigan University (CMU). to earn tenure. The materials document her Scholarly and Creative Activities, Service, and Teaching, including Student Opinion Surveys (SOS), 1988-1990. Also included is biographical information copied from websites, 2006, her vita (16 pp.), and a photograph of her, 1990; the Faculty Mentor Program, TEPD materials, 1988; and the TEPD Handbook, 1990. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Organizational records, 1994,2009.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection documents several initiatives of the Office when Richard Davenport was the Provost, under President Leonard Plachta in the 1990s and under President Mike Rao in 2001. The strategic initiatives include Academic Reorganization of CMU, 1994-1997, and the development and implementation of Core Values under the Steering Committee in 2001. The Strategic Planning Committee, 2001, is also documented. The collection consists of committee agendas, meeting minutes, attachments and related materials, some reports, news releases, emails, and correspondence. The 2009 website for the office and a list of the provosts was added to the collection. The collection is in excellent physical condition. Materials are filed in chronological and then alphabetical order. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:231629309</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kline, Clarence Peter, 1876-1970.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University physics collection, 1924, 1951.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes Cline's 1924 physics laboratory notebook and photographs. The notebook is labeled "C. P. Kline Adv. C. Physics, 1924", for a class he took as a student at the then Central Michigan Normal School (CMNS, late Central Michigan University). It includes his notes and drawings, some of the color spectrum are rendered in colored pencil, for an Optics laboratory, probably a non-calculus class for teachers during a summer institute. Some of the marked pages in the notebook refer to the Brooks Observatory on campus. There are some miscellaneous notes on the inside back cover as well. There is also a black and white photograph, which measures 2.5 x 3.5 inches, of Kline's daughter, Pauline, as a young girl, labeled "C. P.'s Best Girl, Pauline", which is glued to the inside front cover. The photographs (6) are black and white and measure 4.5 x 3.5 inches each. Two of the photographs are of all male physics laboratory classes at CMNS, three show coeducational chemistry laboratory classes at CMNS, and one shows men in uniform waiting outside a building. This photograph is labeled "Ready for chow." The men in uniform are probably SATC (Student Army Training Corps students) and they are standing outside the old physics and chemistry building at CMNS, Merrill Hall. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:38760045</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Huebel, Harriett M.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Huebel, Frances I.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Family papers, 1895,1967.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Family papers, 1895,1967, undated, consist mainly of the papers of Harriet M. Huebel, with some materials of her sister, Frances I. Huebel, and Herbert (Harry) E. Hubel, who was possibly their nephew or cousin. Frances Huebel's papers include her notes from a Traverse City (Mich.) High School cooking class (domestic science), 1910, scrapbook, 1917, and diary, 1915. Harriet Huebel's papers include her nursing diplomas, 1915; correpsondence, 1895,1959, undated; and paperwork and diary, 1918-1919, when she served as a U.S. Army nurse in France during World War I. The diary records her sailing to and from Europe, work, and social activities. She left for Europe in Nov. 1918 and returned in July 1919. There are also many photographs, 1912-1959, mainly of Harriet and nurses, at Peterson Hospital (Ann Arbor, Mich.), later called Ann Arbor Private Hospital, in France, aboard ship en route to or from France, of army hospital staff and patients, views of life and people in France, and a 1931 banquet for World War nurses of the American Legion in Detroit. There are additional photographs of family and friends, as well as Harriett's nursing notes and tests, her hat and pins, biographical materials, and retirement papers. There are also some early 20th century family holiday greeting cards and correspondence between family and friends, 1906-1918, undated. Also included are oversized diplomas for: Harriet from Peterson Hospital (1915); Frances from Traverse City Public School (1912); and Harry from Central State Teachers College, now Central Michigan University (CMU) for a B.S., (1931) and Wayne State University (1944) for a M.A. in Education. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1894,1967.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1894, 1967 and undated include: momentos from Alma College, 1896-1898; papers in German related to his studies at the University of Berlin; his Central Michigan University (CMU) physics class gradebooks, 1910-1947; his obituary (copy), 1964; personal records of Brooks and his wife, Gratia; philosophy, physics, and mathematics notes; and miscellaneous notebooks written by Brooks and two other people. In Prof. Brook's fall 1918 gradebook, some of the students in his physic classes are listed as SATC, or Student Army Training Corps members. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:76961880</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Seestedt, Paul.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 2003-2006.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 2003-2006, include email correspondence with Marian Matyn, Clarke Historical Library Archivist, in 2006 (5 pp.), and 87 pp. of materials Seestedt received or helped create in conjunction with the Central Michigan University (CMU) Athletics Depart. This material includes Football Game Operations Committee meeting agendas and minutes, 2006, and job assignments for  football, basketball, and wrestling events, 2003-2006, noting who was responsible for which duties to prepare and administer sports events, conferences, and tournaments, as well as the deadlines and timelines to accomplish those tasks. Also included is information which was supplied to visiting teams regarding tickets, parking, restaurants, hotels, maps, forms, officials, security issues, and policies for cancellations and inclement weather. Some ticket booth information and a list of the Central Michigan University (CMU) Athletics Depart.'s Hall of Fame Committee chairman's duties, 2006, are also included. This collection offers an example of the behind the scenes preparation necessary to successfully plan and administer various athletics events at CMU. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>

                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>

                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Women's Studies Program.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>She Made A Difference collection, 1992.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes 10 foamcor boards, each measuring 17 x 23 inches, with text and images of ten Central Michigan University women who were included in the 1992 Central Michigan University (CMU) Centennial Project She Made A Difference of the CMU. Women's Studies Program (WSP). The project researched and documented female CMU leaders and the impact they had on CMU. The women documented in this project are Marylea Lombard, Bertha Cobb Ryan, Sarah White Pigeon Sprague, Faith Johnston, Marion Whitney, Catherine O'Connell, Elizabeth Wightman, Jean Mayhew, Grace Laura Ryan, and Nancy Mae Bowers Fleming. The collection is organized alphabetically: Folder 1 has surnames F-O; Folder 2 has surnames R-W. The papers of Johnston, Whitney, and Ryan, as well as the brochure generated from the project, part of the CMU. WSP's organizational records, are also housed at the Clarke Historical Library. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>David Balfour Central State Normal School Photographs, 1915.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Photographs (8) of Central State Normal School, now Central Michigan University, 1915. Photographs are thin, sepia-toned, and measure 2.5 x 3.25 inches each.  There is one image each of the following: four men standing and one sitting in front of the Training School, the Science Building, the old gym, Mr. and Mrs. Hersee with snow on the ground behind them, their two-story house with a woman standing on the steps, and three images of five coeds in long nightgowns surrounded by college pennants on a bed in the Hersee home. in one image they are holding pillows with school names or initials on them, including one for Midland, Michigan. Except for the Hersees, none of the people are identified. Some of the photographs have remnants of tape and black pages from a scrapbook adhered to them. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:78797604</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Freeman, James C.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photographic collection, 1893,1918.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection consists of glass plate negatives (.5 cubic ft. in 1 box) and photographs (.5 cubic ft. in 1 box) of Mount Pleasant (Mich.) downtown buildings, notably the Isabella County Courthouse, the local train and depot, and street scenes; Central Michigan University (CMU) buildings and Mr. Grawn with faculty dated 1917-1918; and the staff, students, and buildings of the Mount Pleasant Indian School. Also included are numerous images of Apache Indians in Ariz. and Sioux Indians in S. D., their Indian schools, staff, and students, and western scenes, including some of the Grand Canyon. A few family portraits are also included. One image of Old Main building at CMU, is dated on the back of the photograph with a note that [an etching of] the image was used in an 1893 newspaper article about the ground breaking of the school. The remaining images, all undated, appear to date from the late 19th century. Most of the photographs were taken by James C. Freeman. A few photographs appear to have been taken by other photographers and added to the collection by Freeman or other family members. A folder of Biographical Materials completes the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Also included are numerous images of Apache Indians in Ariz. and Sioux Indians in S. D., their Indian schools, staff, and students, and western scenes, including some of the Grand Canyon. A few family portraits are also included. One image of Old Main building at CMU, is dated on the back of the photograph with a note that [an etching of] the image was used in an 1893 newspaper article about the ground breaking of the school. A few photographs appear to have been taken by other photographers and added to the collection by Freeman or other family members. A folder of Biographical Materials completes the collection.

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Family Papers, 1933,1951.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Family Papers consist mosty of the diaries and diary transcriptions of Icem C. Slentz, 1933-1948. The diares describe daily weather reports, farm chores, visitors, and local and family news. Interestingly, the only mention of World War II is May 8-9, 1945, Victory in Europe Day. Also included are memoirs of son Floyd Slentz, a biographical sketch of Icem, and a Slentz Family History, 1933-1951. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>The collection consists of 27 black and white photographs, 2.5 x 3.5 inches each, 1937-1938, of men and women in a basement with pool table and shuffleboard, "Central" sign on the wall (10),  an amateur baseball group (5), a photograph of a woman smoking, lake scenes and buildings (5), one of which has the word "Charlevoix" on the ground, portraits of men (7), three of these are of the same man wearing suspenders, and two are of the same man in costume advertising "Dance tonight-Moonlight Gardens"; negatives (7) of the same size and era,  of trees (2), and one each of the man wearing suspenders, a house, the "Charlevoix" image, a field stone building, and chairs set up with Bandoliers music stand covers; photocopies of Central State Life newspaper clippings (7) re: Bandoliers, 1937-1938, mostly advertisements, one image is of the full band with music stand covers for the Bandoliers. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Scrapbook : 1912,1955.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Scrapbook, 1912,1955, includes newspaper clippings; magazine articles; a few postcards; a photograph of a military parade in Milan (Italy), ca. 1920s?, a 1942 war ration book of Helen[a] J. Cobb; a Central Michigan University (CMU) Bulletin, 1918; and two reports on CMU by the Dept. of Agriculture, 1912 and undated. The clippings cover a variety of international topics, mostly during World War II or important people associated with the war, including some obituaries. One article has a photograph of Mrs. Roosevelt visiting CMU onFeb. 16, 1955. The clippings are largely undated, from unidentified sources, and acidic. The pages of the v. are also acidic. The cover is a brown and black speckled color with a red Scotty dog on a leash and "photographs" in capital, red letters. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:51455810</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Student organizations.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1927-1961.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, 1927-1961, undated, includes reports that Central Michigan University (CMU) student groups were required to file each semester with the Student Affairs Committee and administration of CMU. Reports include Treasurer's and President's Semester Reports, Organizational Reports, and Treasurer's Semester Cash Reports. The reports are typed forms with information added by the organization, usually in handwriting. The first two types of reports include the number of business and social meetings held each term, the names and positions of the officers, and names of the members, advisers, honorary members, and patrons of each organization. Other materials that may be included in the collection include organizational constitutions, correspondence and notes about each organization. The folders of the Young Women's Christian Association also include some programs, ca. 1930s, and meeting minutes, 1940s. Some of the correspondence is to Miss Bertha Ronan or Miss D. Louise Sharp. A wide variety of social, Greek, political, volunteer, recreational, athletic, veterans, occupation related, religiously oriented, educational or degree related, ROTC, musical, and graduation class organizations are included in the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Collection, 1927-1961.

The reports are typed forms with information added by the organization, usually in handwriting. The first two types of reports include the number of business and social meetings held each term, the names and positions of the officers, and names of the members, advisers, honorary members, and patrons of each organization. Other materials that may be included in the collection include organizational constitutions, correspondence and notes about each organization. The folders of the Young Women's Christian Association also include some programs, ca. 1930s, and meeting minutes, 1940s. Some of the correspondence is to Miss Bertha Ronan or Miss D. Louise Sharp. A wide variety of social, Greek, political, volunteer, recreational, athletic, veterans, occupation related, religiously oriented, educational or degree related, ROTC, musical, and graduation class organizations are included in the collection.

                     <namePart>French, Agnes Johnson.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1910, 2008.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection includes a copy of French's obituary, 1992, a note from her daughter, Lois Bellinger, 2008, and typed transcriptions of one of four of French's extant diaries, covering the period of  Sept. 11-Nov. 3, 1910 and Feb. 4-21, 1911. The diary begins after Agnes passed her teacher's examination in June 1910. She was teaching in Deerfield Township (Isabella County, Mich.), and living in a boarding house with a large family. Her diary details the loneliness she initially felt being 18 miles from her family, a rough first day of teaching, dating Will, friendship with the family she boarded with, a blizzard on Feb. 6, 1911, visiting friends and family, her emotions and her faith in God. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>President Charles L. Anspach Papers, 1905, 2001.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1905, 2001, and undated. The collection is divided into the following series: Biographical Information (2 cubic ft.), 1912, 2001, undated, including: obituaries (copies), his doctoral dissertation and thesis, certificates, citations, diaries, 1932-1958 (scattered) and 1960-1973; honorary degrees, inauguration materials, scrapbooks, 1948-1959, testimonials and tributes, and his Last Will and Testament, 1977; Correspondence (approx. 1 cubic ft.), 1932-1977, with various individuals, organizations, colleges, boards, and programs; Meeting Minutes (1.5 cubic ft.), 1939-1973, for various CMU departments, committees, and other organizations, councils, and programs; Photographs and Photograph Albums (1.25 cubic ft.), 1941, 1943, 1949-1968, 1971, undated; Reports (approx. 1 cubic ft.), 1937-1941, 1943-1959, 1964, 1970, undated, from CMU departments and committees, and other organizations, councils, and committees; Speeches (4.5 cubic ft.), on a plethora of topics, including speeches recorded on paper, 1929-1976, undated, speeches recorded on reel-to-reel tapes, 1958, 1967, 1971-1973, undated, and programs of speeches given by President Anspach, 1940-1973, undated; Subject Files (4.25 cubic ft.) for a wide variety of CMU organizations, committees, events, a plethora of issues, Michigan and national organizations, councils, boards, and issues of concern to President Anspach, 1931-1977, 1979-1982, undated; Miscellaneous Materials (Memorabilia) (2 cubic ft.), including a wide variety of Masonic, Boy Scout, and CMU memorabilia, 1948, 1950, 1963-1974, undated; Plaques (.5 cubic ft.), 1959, 1964, 1969, 1972-1973, undated, and a Boy Scout Statue, 1943-1945; Index Cards (1 cubic ft.) to Articles and photographs of Anspach in CMU's school newspapers CSLife, later CMLife, 1939-1959. Oversized Materials (approx. 4 cubic ft.), including photographs, photograph albums, 1905-1972 (scattered), certificates, 1946-1976 (scattered), undated, diplomas, 1920, 1923, a resolution, 1967, posters, undated, a guest book, 1939, and miscellaneous, in three flat boxes, complete the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: President Charles L. Anspach Papers, 1905, 2001.
resource.abstract: Papers, 1905, 2001, and undated. The collection is divided into the following series: Biographical Information (2 cubic ft.), 1912, 2001, undated, including: obituaries (copies), his doctoral dissertation and thesis, certificates, citations, diaries, 1932-1958 (scattered) and 1960-1973; honorary degrees, inauguration materials, scrapbooks, 1948-1959, testimonials and tributes, and his Last Will and Testament, 1977; Correspondence (approx. 1 cubic ft.), 1932-1977, with various individuals, organizations, colleges, boards, and programs; Meeting Minutes (1.5 cubic ft.), 1939-1973, for various CMU departments, committees, and other organizations, councils, and programs; Photographs and Photograph Albums (1.25 cubic ft.), 1941, 1943, 1949-1968, 1971, undated; Reports (approx. 1 cubic ft.), 1937-1941, 1943-1959, 1964, 1970, undated, from CMU departments and committees, and other organizations, councils, and committees; Speeches (4.5 cubic ft.), on a plethora of topics, including speeches recorded on paper, 1929-1976, undated, speeches recorded on reel-to-reel tapes, 1958, 1967, 1971-1973, undated, and programs of speeches given by President Anspach, 1940-1973, undated; Subject Files (4.25 cubic ft.) for a wide variety of CMU organizations, committees, events, a plethora of issues, Michigan and national organizations, councils, boards, and issues of concern to President Anspach, 1931-1977, 1979-1982, undated; Miscellaneous Materials (Memorabilia) (2 cubic ft.), including a wide variety of Masonic, Boy Scout, and CMU memorabilia, 1948, 1950, 1963-1974, undated; Plaques (.5 cubic ft.), 1959, 1964, 1969, 1972-1973, undated, and a Boy Scout Statue, 1943-1945; Index Cards (1 cubic ft.) to Articles and photographs of Anspach in CMU's school newspapers CSLife, later CMLife, 1939-1959. Oversized Materials (approx. 4 cubic ft.), including photographs, photograph albums, 1905-1972 (scattered), certificates, 1946-1976 (scattered), undated, diplomas, 1920, 1923, a resolution, 1967, posters, undated, a guest book, 1939, and miscellaneous, in three flat boxes, complete the collection.
resource.displayEntry: Central Michigan University. Office of the President. President Charles L. Anspach Papers, 1905, 2001.

originationNames.name: Central Michigan University. Office of the President.

resourceRelations.content: Central Michigan University. Office of the President. President Charles L. Anspach Papers, 1905, 2001.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:51484610</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University veterans' education records, 1946-1956.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Records for veterans who attended Central Michigan University (CMU), 1946-1956 with surnames beginning with the letter "D" through the letters "McK". The rest of the alphebetical listing is missing. For each veteran there is a typed form of his/her charges at Grover's Central Supply Company (Mount Pleasant, Mich.), which is where CMU students bought their books and supplies, including the date of the term, the veteran's name and address, types and costs of books and supplies that they were allowed for various classes, and the total cost of supplies they purchased. Stapled to each sheet is a 3"x5" card entitled "Veterans Eligibility-Central Michigan College of Education" (form 105b-2). The card is a form with the following information filled in by hand: name, address, and student identification number of the veteran; which branch of the U.S. Armed Forces the veteran served in; the service identification number, marital status, and number of children, if any, of the veteran; if the veteran was eligible to attend CMU under Public Law 346 (GI Bill) or 16 (GI Rehabilitation); the dates the semester began and ended; curriculum studied and total credits of Physical Education taken by the veteran; if the veteran had registered under the GI Bill; and the dated signature of the Dean of Men. Some cards have also been stamped with names of administrators and the word "accepted". Part of the collection includes Master (Book) Lists for Veterans. For each term, this includes a set of typed forms in alphabetical order by the name of each CMU department. On the page/s for each department are listed the courses offered that term, in order by course number. Pages with changes in course lists, correspondence between people in various CMU departments or between Grover's and N.C. Bovee, then CMU's Business Manager, and some lists of eligible veterans are included. The papers of two women, Violet Flower, 1950-1951, and Lillian Wiltse McDougald, 1951, are included. Additional papers of Hans Lantzsch and records of N.C. Bovee, are also housed in the Clarke. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:54465064</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Lyon, Norm.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1929,1991.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1929,1991, and undated includes photographic materials (film negatives, strip negatives of multiple images, single image negatives, photographs, photograph and negative albums, transparencies, slides, partial reels of film, and paste-ups) as well as paper (correspondence, reports, articles, newspaper clippings, obituaries, maps, and other materials.) The collection documents three aspects of Norm Lyon's life and work: his personal and family life; his work as an oil field reporter and photographer for the Michigan Oil & Gas News (MOGN); and his work as a photographer for the Mount Pleasant Daily Times News (MPDTN). The smallest part of the collection documents Norm's family life mostly in negatives and a few photographs, dating mostly 1935-1945. This part of the collection shows Norm's wife and children, their holidays, homelife, vacations camping, trips to Niagara Falls and Leonidas (Mich.), the children in Halloween costumes, playing with friends and toys, Christmas celebrations, the family dog "Rip", Phyllis' and Norm's club activities, particularly the Mount Pleasant Kiwanis Club and the Pere Marquette Club, card parties with friends, and their relatives. Life in and around Mount Pleasant (Mich.) as recorded for the MPDTN is a larger part of the collection. Most of the images are negatives and include downtown Mount Pleasant parades, holidays, sales, politics, juries, veterans, various board meetings, various clubs and organizations, the dedication of the Indian Hall on July 7, 1940, Isabella County Fairs, 1947-1948 and 1956; the opening or dedication of the new airport and swimming pool, schools and students. Other local areas documented include the Pre-Edenville dam, Reed City, Ithaca, Arenac, and Armada, among others. Central Michigan University (CMU) is documented as well, mostly in negatives. Of note are images of the cornerstone ceremony at Rachel Tate hall, 1956, the construction of the Arts & Crafts Building, 1947, the 1936 College Hop, Doc Sweeney's Gym Troupe, the Football Team, sports, and Homecoming events, ca. 1930s, all negatives, and  photographs of the Training School fire of Jan. 8, 1933. Various other topics for the mid-Michigan area are also included and are detailed in the finding aid. The largest group of negatives and photographs documents all aspects of oil exploration and production in Michigan, 1930s-1980s, as well as in a few other states. A large group of negatives and photographs documents men in the oil business, both workers in the field and Association members, usually at meetings and parties, 1930s-1970s. Other images of groups of men or individuals show them  relaxing, hunting, fishing, or working in businesses unrelated to oil. Portraits of individuals connected with the oil and the Purple Gang include Isaiah Leebove and Jack Livingston. Other men not connected with oil include Spikehorn Meyer,  and Michigan governors Soapy Williams, George Romney, and Kim Sigler. Numerous topics related to oil exploration and production are well documented within the collection including: buildings and plants, oil fires and explosions, derricks, refineries, oil expositions, 1935-1937, land leases, sales, and landsmen, gas and gas plants, brine, oil well sites, pipes, gas stations, storage tanks, pumps, sinkholes, equipment, and various vehicles. Plants or buildings well documented include: Gaylord (Mich.), Gulf Oil Co., Hilliard's, Kalkaska (Mich.), Shell Oil Co., McClure, the Porter fields, Pure Oil Co., Reed City (Mich.), Roosevelt Refinery (Mount Pleasant, Mich.), Saginaw (Mich.), Sun Oil Co., Tekonsha, and Wise Township (Isabella County, Mich.). Fires well documented include: Roosevelt fire, 1933, Six Lakes fire, 1974, Sturble Well fire, 1934, and Woods Well fire, ca. 1930s. The papers document oil leases, reports, articles and reprints of articles, and clippings, obituaries, and correspondence of Norm and others. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>Papers, 1925, include two diplomas from Central Michigan Normal School (CMNS), now Central Michigan University, granting Josephine Sommerville a lifetime teaching certificate, dated June 23, 1925. There is also a brief biography provided by her daughter, Janet Cassebaum of Ann Arbor (Mich.), who donated the collection. </abstract>

                     <role>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:60521842</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Colby, Alice J. Wesley.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1923,1998.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include: black and white photographs, two of which are of Alice and her friends at Central Michigan University (CMU), 1923, and four of which are of school children she taught in Sparta (Mich.), 1929; her 1929 diary; obituaries for Alice, Oct. 11, 1996, and her husband, William Colby, Oct. 7, 1957; and a brochure for their endowed scholarship at CMU, 1998. The diary, which cover Jan. 1-June 16, 1929, briefly notes her daily activities and accounts. She taught in Sparta from Jan. 2-June 13.  During that time, Alice boarded with Bill and Freda King, attended the Methodist Church, Bridge Club, sports and plays, school teachers meetings, and went to the library often. At the end of the term she graded exams and papers, compiled grades, attended graduation, and then returned to her parents' home. Her diary is blank after June 16. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>The collection, 1905, 2006, and undated, documents the department and its related student organizations. The Central Michigan University (CMU) Dept. of Home Economics, now called the Dept. of Human Environmental Studies, is documented by Organizational Histories and Research Notes, compiled and written in 1996 by Donna Poynor; Photographs, 1930s-1960s, 1990s, and 2003; Published Materials, 1944-1984 (Scattered); Slides, 1950s, 1961, and undated; pages from the department's 2006 website; a Sewing I Notebook and teacher contracts, 1905-1913; a Scrapbook, 1961-1963; Annual Reports, 1960s; and Departmental Correspondence, 1960s, both of a general nature and some specific to the renovation of Wightman Hall. The Dept. of Home Economics, Family Life and Consumer Education is documented by a publication, Quest for Values, 1968-1969, by Evelyn I. Rouner. Tthe Central Home Economics Club is documented by Constitutions, 1941-1987 (Scattered); Meeting Minutes of both regular and Executive Council meetings, and Lists of Members, 1920-1989 (Scattered); and Scrapbooks, 1942,  1946-1948, 1958-1963 (1 v.) and 1958-1964 (1 v.). The club experienced several name changes through the years. As the Central Michigan Home Economics Association, it is documented by Scrapbooks, 1977-1979 (2 v.), and, later, as the CMU Home Economics Association, it is documented by a Scrapbook, 1979-1980. The club was a member of the state-wide Michigan Home Economics Association, which is documented by Scrapbooks, 1936-1938, and 1982-1984. Kappa Omicron Phi, the National Home Economics Honors Society,  is documented by a Photograph Album, 1978-1983 and two Scrapbooks, 1961-1977, and 1973-1982. (For more detailed information, see the finding aid.) </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:770669255</recordOrigin>

                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Westie, Ardith Wingier.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Westie, Elizabeth,</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Charles and Ardith Westie Collection, 1938-c. 2010; 1941-1955.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Charles and Ardith Westie Collection spans 1938-circa 2010.  Of special interest are letters from World War II.  Charles participated in the Normandy campaign, was wounded in July 1944 and then spent the remainder of his service in military hospitals.  During this time, Ardith raised their daughter alone.  Living in Lansing, Michigan, she worked as a staff writer for the Michigan Education Association.  The Westies maintained a prolific two-way correspondence, which has been preserved within the collection.  Also documented are the couple's pre-war courtship and marriage and the birth of their first child.  Post-war materials document Charles' time as a sociology doctoral student at Ohio State University and as an Assistant Professor of Sociology and Director of Research, Continuing Education Service at Michigan State University.  Includes copies of his 1953 dissertation, "Reactions of Railroad Workers to a Major Technological Change" and other research papers. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>State Archive of Michigan</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Family Papers, 1898-1987.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Family Papers, 1898-1987 include the papers of Michigan sisters, Nellie Mae and Verna Lucil[l]e Campbell, sisters, who graduated from Central Michigan Normal School (CMNS) and Central State Teachers College (CSTC), now Central Michigan University and taught for many years in Michigan and Ohio schools. Included are their obituaries, 1948, 1987, teaching and graduation certificates, 1915-1916, 1920, 1923, 1930-1931, Nellie's transcripts, 1924-1930,her 1900 CMNS graduation program, her paper on the history of CSTC, her 1973 50th anniversary scrapbook for the class of 1923, and Verna's 1910 CSNS graduation program. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:48513538</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Osborn, Wayne H.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1959,2010.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection is divided into three series: Osborn Papers; Central Michigan University (CMU) Materials; and CMU Physics Department Materials.  The Osborn Papers, 1965-2007, and undated (2 cubic ft.), consist mainly of his personal work and research correspondence, notes, and data, published articles, teaching materials, and biographical information. His research proposals, reports, notes, articles, photographs and other related materials on the Coleman Meteorite, and his research projects at both the Hubble Space Telescope and at the National Underground Research Observatory (NURO) at Lowell Observatory, Flagstaff (Ariz.) are documented in this series. Also in this series are Osborn's correspondence developing an agreement with NURO to bring CMU students there to conduct astronomical observations, 1993-2001, as well as his professional and research correspondence with Dr. Francisco Fuenmayor and Dr. Antonio Luis Cardenas, both of the Universidad de Los Andes in Merida, Venezula, 2000-2001 and 1970-1976, respectively, and his correspondence with Juan Jose Claria, 1976-1979. The Claria and some of the Cardenas correspondence is in Spanish. The CMU Materials, 1959,2006 (approx. 1 cubic ft.), consists mainly of memos, meeting minutes, reports, and other materials of a substantial nature, documenting changes in policy, procedure or interests at CMU, accreditation issues, various policies, legal opinions, and documentation of the search for a new provost in 2002. The CMU. Physics Department Materials, 1968-2006 (approx. 3.5 cubic ft.) consists mainly of departmental and various committee meeting minutes, 1976-2006; student manuals and study guides for astronomy and physics classes mainly taught by Osborn, 1976-2005 (Scattered); department publications, brochures, and strategic planning documents; and the departmental constitution and bylaws. There are also a few materials Osborn helped generate such as the Off-Campus Observatory Proposal and Study, 1968-1976, his Colloquia and Seminar Notes, 1980-2006, and various departmental program reviews, 1981-1998 (Scattered), and proposals. Miscellaneous materials complete the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>William H. Rivard Collection, 1951, 1999.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection includes a wide range of musical compositions composed by Dr. Rivard, 1951-1999. The are compositions for orchestra, band, small instrumental groups and solos, and voice. These pieces may include conductor's scores and/or various instrumental parts. While a few of the pieces have been published and copyrighted, most are unpublished. They are all in good physical condition. For processing reasons, the collection was organized by size, and then alphabetically by title. Sometimes because of size differences, the score is physically separated form the other musical parts. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:224540161</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Public Relations and Marketing.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photographic collection, 1962-2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists mainly of photographs, 1962-2002, and undated, both black and white and colored, of various sizes, and also proof sheets, some on cardboard, and some negatives. The collection documents a wide variety of Central Michigan University (CMU) staff, students, programs, departments, and events, as well as related images of Mount Pleasant (Mich.) and the Korean Orphanage CMU students used to financially support. Some portraits in the collection predate 1962. Also, some photographs in the collection were taken by private photographers. There are two alphabetical runs in this collection due to the way it was transferred to the Clarke. Due to its size, this collection cannot be interfiled into the original CMU. Photographs collection which is housed in filing cabinets. An inventory is available to assist researchers interested in using the earlier collection of photographs. After 2002 all CMU photographs were taken with digital cameras. Peggy Brisbane and Robert Barclay took many of the photographs in this collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:51585275</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Fox, Bernice M.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan Normal scrapbook, 1891,1925.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Scrapbook, 1891,1925, has a red cover and leather tie. Fox's name, Central Michigan Normal, 1891, and the Michigan state seal are on the front cover in gold. Central Michigan Normal School later became Central Michigan University (CMU). The pages have fine, printed illustrations. Included in the v. are autographs, 1919-1922, with each signer's address, birthday, and thoughts; newspaper clippings about CMU faculty, students, and sports; photographs of CMU students, some in play (theater) costumes, buildings, and events, such as damage to the campus from a sleet storm of Feb. 22, 1922; notes, letters; programs; brochures and tickets of a trip to Colo.; a pin of Central State Teachers Assn., 1922; two ribbons with a "C", and receipts for tuition, 1922. After Fox graduated in 1922, there are notes, programs, clippings, and photographs from Maple Rapids High School (Mich.) and Middleton High School (Mich.); postcards of CMU, Colo., and Wyo., photographs of stock yards in Omaha (Neb.); and commencement programs, 1924-1925, for Middleton High School. Also included is some biographical information on Fox, (2 p., copies) from the 1922 Chippewa yearbook. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Included in the v. are autographs, 1919-1922, with each signer's address, birthday, and thoughts; newspaper clippings about CMU faculty, students, and sports; photographs of CMU students, some in play (theater) costumes, buildings, and events, such as damage to the campus from a sleet storm of Feb. 22, 1922; notes, letters; programs; brochures and tickets of a trip to Colo.; a pin of Central State Teachers Assn., 1922; two ribbons with a "C", and receipts for tuition, 1922. After Fox graduated in 1922, there are notes, programs, clippings, and photographs from Maple Rapids High School (Mich.) and Middleton High School (Mich.); postcards of CMU, Colo., and Wyo., photographs of stock yards in Omaha (Neb.); and commencement programs, 1924-1925, for Middleton High School.                   </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Idella Seabolt papers, 1941, 2011.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include: Central Michigan College, now Central Michigan University (CMU) of Education, Division of Student Personnel, Guide Book for Education Development, 1941, 12 p. published booklet. The booklet includes sections a student could fill in about their academic objectives, counselors, time distribution plan, vocational preferences, secondary school and transferred college credits, test data psychograph, questionnaire data psychograph, course plan, social participation record, personal skills record, record of courses, and personal objectives. All but the first page is blank. Also included is a typed list (2 p.) of rooming houses for women students at Central State Teachers College, Summer session 1941, including for each house, the name of owner, address, phone number, rate, if light housekeeping is expected, number of girls rooming in house, double or single rooms; and a letter (1 p.) 2011, providing biographical information on Idella. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:51254995</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Office of the President.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Boyd, William B.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>President William B. Boyd Papers, 1968-1978.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include Biographical Information, 1968-1974 (5 folders); Correspondence, 1968-1978 (about 1 cubic ft.); Meeting Minutes from Central Michigan University (CMU) entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1968-1978 (about 1 cubic ft.); a few Photographs, 1969-1971, undated (more are in the Subject Files); Reports from CMU entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1968-1978, undated (about 1 cubic ft.); Speeches, 1968-1975 (9 folders); and Subject Files, 1968-1978, undated, on a wide variety of topics relating to education, CMU, and numerous CMU departments (7.75 cubic ft.), including Congratulatory letters on the occasion of Boyd's inauguration as CMU's seventh president on April 25, 1960 (2 folders). Financial reports, 1970-1975 are also included. The heart of the collection is in the Subject Files, which documents the change of focus for CMU during President Boyd's tenure. Projects, issues, students, and committees regarding social and racial issues, affirmative action, diversity, and minorities predominate. "Problem" students and organizations, student concerns, the Vietnam Moratorium, the Cultural Center, and issues concerning the faculty are also highlighted. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1910,2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1910, 2002, and undated, consists mostly of Dain's materials relating to the Children of the Chippewa, Ottawa, and Potawatomi versus the Regents of the University of Michigan trial, 1971-1980; his research papers and drafts; materials for county or city events he collected or helped create; papers of students; biographical materials; and some miscellaneous maps (copies). Other materials relating to the trial may be found in the Elmer White papers and cataloged materials. Papers by students include: History of events culminating inthe removal of the Nottawa-Sippe band of Potawatomi Indians, by John M. Leatherbury, 1977; History of Isabella County, by Mrs. Stephen Potter, 1910, and New York to Michigan : the all water route of the 1840s, by James D. Gries, 1974; and Vernon Township Records, 1941-1942, by Harriet E. Morton, ca. 1942? </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:45031884</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University war years collection, 1947-1972.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection of materials documenting Central Michigan University alumni of graduation classes of 1938-1948. The collection includes photographs (5); digitized photographs (8); list of alumni, 1938-1948; newspaper clipping (copy, undated); compilation of CMLife newsletter (1/10-6/13/1945); Reunion news: war years, 1938-1948, with biographies and photographs of alumni; and CMC Honors V-12, a compilation of information, photographs, and articles about CMU alumni, the football team, and those who served in the armed forces during the war years, 1947-1972. Some of the photographs are of the alumni while they were students on campus, while others document the 25th and 50th war years reunions. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:46674712</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Associated Women Students.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Organizational records, 1928-1970.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Organizational records include Meeting Minutes of the club, 1943-1960, and the Women's League, 1928-1942, probably its predecessor; Photographs, undated; Reports, 1943-1956, undated; Subject Files documenting the group's interests and activities, 1941-1965, undated, and Constitutions, 1940-1971 (Scattered), and Meeting Programs, 1940-1972; a Guest Book, undated; and Scrapbooks, 1940-1970, undated, and three Oversized Scrapbooks, 1943-1944, 1964-1967, and 1967-1968. Scrapbooks include: photographs; artwork; newspaper and magazine articles; dance programs; notes; correspondence; and miscellaneous. Marjorie Anderson, later the wife of Senator Robert Griffin, was the president of the Associated Women Students (AWS) in 1943. The organization's newsletters, Associated Women Students Newsletter 1960-1971, and Women Today, 1972-ca. 1974, are cataloged separately. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Scrapbooks include: photographs; artwork; newspaper and magazine articles; dance programs; notes; correspondence; and miscellaneous. Marjorie Anderson, later the wife of Senator Robert Griffin, was the president of the Associated Women Students (AWS) in 1943. The organization's newsletters, Associated Women Students Newsletter 1960-1971, and Women Today, 1972-ca. 1974, are cataloged separately.
resource.extent: 4.5 cubic ft. (in 5 boxes, 3 Oversized v.) : ill.

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Building records, 1953-1955 and 1959-1962, for Central Michigan University's Married Student Apartments and Merrill and Sweeney halls.                      <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1919-1933, include correspondence to Collins, from his mother, Mount Pleasant (Mich.) about family affairs, Jan. 10, 1933; from P.G. Lantz, Superintendent of the Training School at Central Michigan Normal School, now Central Michigan University, to Collins at Junior High School, Stambaugh (Mich.) about his teaching career, April 6, 1925; and one from Rev. Joseph H. Green, First Presbyterian Church, about a speech Collins gave at a service honoring Mr. and Mrs. Charles Slater, Nov. 24, 1919, including the program with photographs of the Slaters. The Slaters' obituaries (copies) are included. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:320244008</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Osborn, John K. (John Kenneth), 1904-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1931, 2009.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1931-1938 and 2009 (copies), mainly consist of correspondence to/from Osborn divided alphabetically by topic. The Central Michigan University (CMU) correspondence is between Osborn, Professor David M. Trout, and CMU President Eugene C. Warriner. A letter of September 13, 1938 from Trout to Osborn notes the severe housing shortage and salary cuts by the Governor of Michigan from July 1 through September 1, 1938, and a desire to hire Osborn in 1939. The Hillsdale correspondence focuses on getting Osborn's thesis published and finding a job, as well as his correspondence with Willfred Mauck, then President of Hillsdale College, about the Teacher Training Program which Osborn directed. A few of Osborn's student papers form the University of Michigan, a report about the Teacher Training Program at Hillsdale, two bibliographies, and biographical materials complete the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1931, 2009.

The Central Michigan University (CMU) correspondence is between Osborn, Professor David M. Trout, and CMU President Eugene C. Warriner. A letter of September 13, 1938 from Trout to Osborn notes the severe housing shortage and salary cuts by the Governor of Michigan from July 1 through September 1, 1938, and a desire to hire Osborn in 1939. The Hillsdale correspondence focuses on getting Osborn's thesis published and finding a job, as well as his correspondence with Willfred Mauck, then President of Hillsdale College, about the Teacher Training Program which Osborn directed. A few of Osborn's student papers form the University of Michigan, a report about the Teacher Training Program at Hillsdale, two bibliographies, and biographical materials complete the collection.

                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Enders, Calvin W., 1926-1997.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Michigan Ku Klux Klan Research Papers, 1917,1997.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1917-1997 and undated, includes Enders' research papers documenting the Ku Klux Klan, mostly about the Michigan Klan. The papers include: demographics; articles Enders wrote to be published; articles copied from other sources including books, magazines, and newspapers; membership cards, photographic materials; and memorabilia. Membership cards may contain census or local election notes of Enders' or marital status, type of employment, children, and address information on individual Klan members. Various types of photographic images include Michigan Klan parades, meetings, a funeral, and the Chicora KKK quilt with members' names embroidered on it. The collection also includes a sheeted figurine, Klan songbooks and copied articles from Klan newspapers. The collection is very valuable in documenting individual Klan members, both men and women, in Michigan prior to 1924. There is also substantial documentation of the activities of local Michigan Klans. The attempts to elect a Detroit Klan mayor in 1924 and ban private Michigan schools are well documented, as are the financial problems and the high profile murders committed by Klan officials that led to the Klan's fall from political power in 1924. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Head, Library Depart. Papers, 1931,1982.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers of Orville L. Eaton (1912-1974) and Charles V. Park (1885-1982) who were heads of what is now Park Library from 1958-1968 and 1931-1957, respectively. The records include: committee meeting minutes, reports, statistics, opinion surveys, equipment lists, correspondendence, and opening ceremony brochures for the library's new building, now Ronan Hall, and the newer  Park Library expansion plans and photographs. Basic administrative policies and manuals are included, as are the correspondence and meeting minutes of Alpha Beta Alpha, the national undergraduate Library Science fraternity, of which Eaton was the advisor. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>

                  <abstract>Collection of the records of the Committee, 1949-1966, including: testimony and records of witnesses, correspondence, notes of Committee members, newspaper clippings, related published materials, hearing schedules, and other materials. The findings and recommendations of the Committee were issued in a final report, a copy of which is also available at the Clarke Historical Library. Some of the newspaper clippings include photographs. </abstract>
