                     <title>New library collection, 1996-2008.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>New library collection, 1998-2008, includes: newspaper and magazine clippings, invitations, menus, programs, photographs, e-photographs from the library's webpage, memos, and a relocation timetable. The collection documents the library during construction of the new building, the opening and dedication of the new building. Also included are the Federal Depository Program 50th Anniversary (CD-R), Jan. 24, 2008, and the library's official opening (CD-R), Jan. 9, 2002, various publications of exhibits and events, news articles, website pages, reports, and brochures generated since 2002. Materials used to plan the new library, 3 CDs of construction and dedication photographs, and 19 sets of photographs mounted on foamcor board are also included. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photographs, 1977-1989.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection consists of 8"x10" and 12"x15" black and white photographs of the students in Prof. Chaffee's various physics classes at Central Michigan University, 1977-1989. Most of the photographs have paper attached to them with an outline of each student in the photograph, as well as their name. Apparently, Chaffee used the photographs to help him identify students during class time. An occasional syllabus, test, or experiment project outline are included with the photographs. Chaffee's obituary, January 22, 1991 (a copy) is also included. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:695585803</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Knott, Robert B.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1884, 1985.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Robert Knott Papers, 1884, 1985, and undated, consist of biographical information, high school related records, personal correspondence, photographs, newspaper clippings, individual writings and World War II memorabilia. The topically grouped material is arranged alphabetically. Photographs include the Knott family, the Knott family farm, and Robert Knott's military service. Personal writings cover Knott's childhood, teaching in Japan and working on the family farm. Correspondence includes letters and postcards to Robert Knott from family and acquaintances. This collection contains a World War II Victory Pack of postcards. This collection also includes Robert Knott's dog tags, World War II pins, and a World War II honor medal. Of interest is a notebook, 1884, written in German, which contains notes and comments on books, the 23rd Psalm, poems, authors, and English recipes. One oversize folder contains a large picture of Robert Knott, materials related to Carson City High School, and baggage paperwork from his travel to Japan by ship. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1884, 1985.

The topically grouped material is arranged alphabetically. Photographs include the Knott family, the Knott family farm, and Robert Knott's military service. Personal writings cover Knott's childhood, teaching in Japan and working on the family farm. Correspondence includes letters and postcards to Robert Knott from family and acquaintances. This collection contains a World War II Victory Pack of postcards. This collection also includes Robert Knott's dog tags, World War II pins, and a World War II honor medal. Of interest is a notebook, 1884, written in German, which contains notes and comments on books, the 23rd Psalm, poems, authors, and English recipes. One oversize folder contains a large picture of Robert Knott, materials related to Carson City High School, and baggage paperwork from his travel to Japan by ship.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:503472231</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Forrister, Luella D. W.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central State Normal School photographs and postcards, 1911-1912.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>17 black and white postcards and photographs of life at Central State Normal School (CSNS), 1911-1912 and undated [circa 1912]. Images include three different group photographs of members of Pi Kappa Sigma Sorority, February 3,1912, many with fur muffs; 1 postcard of Lena Palley, Zola Cronin and Luella Wright, labeled as Des Moines Club from Stickle Broadway Club, undated [circa 1912]; 2 postcards of women chorus and clergy standing outside next to St. John's Episcopal Church, Mount Pleasant, Easter 1911 and 1912, women wearing mortarboards and carrying music; 4 photographs of various images of Ethel Raynor, Luella Wright, Ruth Orser, Owen Sanders, and Brit (a man) inside houses where they lived while attending CSNS, 1912; 1 postcard of a mixed chorus on a small stage [in Old Main auditorium] labeled "chorus", undated [circa 1912]; 5 postcards of women in long, white dresses on field for May-Pole Pagent, May 26, 1911, includes: May-Pole Dance, Rose Drill, Indian Club Drill (front and rear images), Japanese dance (with parasols, fake kimonos and fake Japanese hairstyles). Ruth Orser and Luella Wright are identified on the May-Pole Dance postcard. Also included is 1 summer photograph of the Chippewa River, Mount Pleasant, Mich., undated [circa 1912]. Images vary in size from 5.5x2.5 to 3.5x5.5 inches. All are in good condition. Some images have handwritten notes in pencil or ink on the back. One of the postcards was mailed in 1912. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Central State Normal School photographs and postcards, 1911-1912.
resource.abstract: 17 black and white postcards and photographs of life at Central State Normal School (CSNS), 1911-1912 and undated [circa 1912]. Images include three different group photographs of members of Pi Kappa Sigma Sorority, February 3,1912, many with fur muffs; 1 postcard of Lena Palley, Zola Cronin and Luella Wright, labeled as Des Moines Club from Stickle Broadway Club, undated [circa 1912]; 2 postcards of women chorus and clergy standing outside next to St. John's Episcopal Church, Mount Pleasant, Easter 1911 and 1912, women wearing mortarboards and carrying music; 4 photographs of various images of Ethel Raynor, Luella Wright, Ruth Orser, Owen Sanders, and Brit (a man) inside houses where they lived while attending CSNS, 1912; 1 postcard of a mixed chorus on a small stage [in Old Main auditorium] labeled "chorus", undated [circa 1912]; 5 postcards of women in long, white dresses on field for May-Pole Pagent, May 26, 1911, includes: May-Pole Dance, Rose Drill, Indian Club Drill (front and rear images), Japanese dance (with parasols, fake kimonos and fake Japanese hairstyles). Ruth Orser and Luella Wright are identified on the May-Pole Dance postcard. Also included is 1 summer photograph of the Chippewa River, Mount Pleasant, Mich., undated [circa 1912]. Images vary in size from 5.5x2.5 to 3.5x5.5 inches. All are in good condition. Some images have handwritten notes in pencil or ink on the back. One of the postcards was mailed in 1912.
resource.displayEntry: Forrister, Luella D. W. Central State Normal School photographs and postcards, 1911-1912.

resourceRelations.content: Forrister, Luella D. W. Central State Normal School photographs and postcards, 1911-1912.

                  <abstract>Each sepia colored commercial print is on cream paper, measures 18 x 14 inches. Also included is the Whitehead Farms barn (purchased by George W. Whitehead in 1876) Union Township, Isabella County, Mich., and Mount Pleasant Fire Department Engine (Firetruck) No. 1, made in 1921 by the Transport Truck Company of Mount Pleasant. Some of the pages are turning yellow due to acidification. Otherwise the prints are in good condition. The initial art work may have been graphite drawings. </abstract>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>McDougal family papers includes  tribute certificates to Lowell and Vivian Helen (Yeo) McDougal from the Grand Rapids [Mich.] Board of Education, undated [before 1975]; and for Helen, her Central Michigan Normal School (CMNS, later Central Michigan University, CMU), transcript, July 14, 1925, and her Saginaw, East Side, High School transcript, which includes classes she took and grades she earned, 1918-1922, noting her graduation on June 22, 1922, dated July 22, 1922. Also included is a letter (photocopy) from their nephew, Robert A. McDougal, M. D., to CMU providing biographical information on his aunt, uncle, and father. Please note that some materials Doctor McDougal described in his letter, were missing when the collection arrived in the Clarke Historical Library. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

                     <title>Personnel cards, 1962-1974.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Personnel Cards of all faculty, administration, and staff at Central Michigan University, 2 boxes are 1967-1974, 1 box is 1962-1973. The 8x4 inch cards include for each person: name, address, dates of birth and hire, degrees, university where each degree was earned, rank at which person was hired, promotions attained, dates of promotions and/or pay increases, department name, and amount of each pay increase. Extra notes are included for summer school and department chairs. Most cards have a black and white photograph of the person attached. Some photographs are missing, while others are detached and filed in front of the appropriate card. Cards are filed alphabetically by surnames. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:213379927</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Brandell, Richard R.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Michigan postcard collection, 1908-1960.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Six albums of postcards (330 postcards), ca. 1908-1960. Postcards are black and white or colored, some are tinted, and some have attachments made of felt. The images are all of Mount Pleasant (Mich.) unless otherwise specified. Some of the postcards are quite rare. Vol. 1 includes postcards of Mount Pleasant (Mich.) buildings, advertisements, bridges, parks, rivers, generic floral and cute images, Michigan maps, Mount Pleasant churches, Spikehorn (John E. Meyer) of Harrison (Mich.) feeding bears, and damage caused by the Fowlerville cyclone of May 15, 1909. Vol. 2 includes postcards of generic Native Americans and racist depictions of African Americans. Vol. 3 includes postcards of the Mount Pleasant Indian School band, buildings, and student groups. Vol. 4 includes postcards of Central Michigan University buildings,  gym classes attired in bloomers, a few interior building views, and a few composite images of buildings. Vol. 5 includes postcards of local oil fields, oil equipment, and oil well or derrick fires, the Roosevelt Refinery, trains, and damage caused by ice storms. Vol. 6 includes postcards of churches, including Zion Lutheran, Methodist, and Sacred Heart, schools, public buildings, streets, farm animals, and advertising. An addition to the collection includes 1 box of 330 postcards of Mount Pleasant area history. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Mount Pleasant (Mich.) postcards slide collection, 1908,1986.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Slide collection made from Mount Pleasant (Mich.) postcards, dating from 1908-1970s, created by Benford in 1986. The slides are in color and black and white, and divided into the following Mount Pleasant (Mich.) topics: Buildings and houses (24); Central Michigan University (CMU, 47); Downtown (42), which includes some icestorm images; Miscellaneous (24), which includes churches (6), bridges (5), oil-related images (4), trains and depots (2), and general (7); Plants and mills (125); and the U.S. Indian School and other local schools (21). Most of the postcards have handwritten notes, in ink, identifying the image. Some of the images are dated when originally photographed, either on the image or in handwritten notes, in ink. The slides are in very good condition. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:56099589</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Athletic Field Corporation.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Scrapbook, 1930,1957.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The scrapbook includes: a letter from Park G. Lantz, Superintendent of the Training School at Central State Teachers College, later Central Michigan University (CMU), to Pres. E.C. Warriner, Jan. 14, 1930, listing the steps of a plan to buy the property needed for a new athletic park and the cost and requirements of such a park for 31,000 dollars on 22 acres of property bordered by Mission, Preston, Franklin, and Bellows streets in Mount Pleasant (Mich.); the By-Laws of the Corporation, with Meeting Minutes, June 28, 1930-Oct. 18, 1938 (scattered, the last minutes mention later events of Juy 10, 1942); Certificates of incorporation from the State of Mich., Dept. of State, May 5, 1930 and May 21, 1931; a Notice from the members of the Corporation's board informing Prof. George DePuy that he will fill Prof. Tambling's position on the board, Oct. 27, 1937; and Correspondence from Joe P. Carey re: Mr. Ron W. Finch checking on the deed to the Althletic Field and finding out about the Corporation, April 12, 1957, and an attached undated cover note from Joe to Ron; Correspondence from Ron W. Finch to Pres. Anspach, May 9, 1957, explaining how CMU professors and alumni, who when students paid 3 dollars/term to pay off the loans needed to buy and build the field, are against buildings being built on the property; and Correspondence from Pres. Anspach to J.P. Carey re: their previous letter and the probability that the field will be moved elsewhere, so the unhappy alumni will hopefully be appeased. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:56139666</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>

                     <namePart>Michigan. Dept. of Management and Budget.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Conspectus of the physical plant, 1942,1944.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Conspectus includes a cover letter from Adrian N. Langius, Dir. of the Mich. State Administrative Board. Buildings and Construction Div., Nov. 1944, and briefs, construction drawings, and photographs (for most of)Central Michigan University's existing buildings in 1944, which included: Warriner Hall, the old Fieldhouse, Sloan Hall, the first Ronan Hall, the Elementary School, which was part of the College of Education's Training School, Grawn Science Hall, the old Gymnasium, Keeler Union, later called Powers Hall, the Powerhouse, and the temporary structures for the Woodworking Shop, Industrial Arts and Social Science. Photographs are not included for the temporary structures. Roger Allen, Architect, wrote the briefs in June 1942, which include the following information about each building: date built, source of funding, name of architect, cubic feet, architectural construction information, mechanical information, and evaluation of overall condition of building, with suggestions for improvements or demolition. The temporary buildings and old Gymnasium were in very bad condition by 1944 and needed to be replaced. A copy of the conspectus was sent to CMU. College of Education. Buildings in the conspectus which still exist include Warriner, Powers, and Sloan. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Public school photograph, 192u-193u.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>An unrolled, oversized black and white photograph of middle and high school students and teachers, standing and sitting in front of an unidentified school building, believed to be somewhere in Clare County (Mich.), undated (ca. 1920-1930). A few primary school-age students are visible in the basement and first floor classroom windows. The donor (Evelyn Roy)'s Mother, Rachel Woods, is believed to be the girl with the big white hairbow and white collar in the center of the front row. The photograph measures 8x28 inches. It is damaged with rips and stains, and is missing one corner. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

               </mods>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:277152657</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Westie, Charles M.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photographic album, 1850-1865.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Small album with worn brown leather embossed cover. The lock is missing and the spine is loose. The album is basically in two pieces. The first page includes "the Photographic Album" in decorative gold script, published in New York, followed by a blank index page.The album includes 24 pp. of family images from circa 1850-1865, none of which are dated, many of which are partially identified. Included are various sizes and formats of photographs of women (5), men (10), girls (4), babies (1), boys (1), a boy and a girl (1). One photograph is missing. One image is actually a copy of a painted woman. Some of the photographs are tinted. Two of the men are wearing Civil War uniforms. Among the families documented here are those named Dexter, Hoard, Gleason, Stiles, Carry, Newl, and Mason. The album was possibly a family album of the donor, Prof. Charles M. Westie. No locations or names of photographers are viewable without causing further damage to the album. The album is fragile and should be used with care by researchers. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:38002768</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Keller, Mark, 1950-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1815,2010.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection is composed mostly of photocopies of Keller's reference files, reports, correspondence, and a cassette tape. The reports include: the Canal lands of Keweenaw Bay : a report for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, Michigan Agency, 38 p., 1984; a Micro model of leadership among the Ojibwa of southeast Michigan and their descendants, 58 p. [89 p.], with a cassette tape of oral interviews with Norman Landosky and Ron Douglas on Aug. 28-29, 1995, which were used to create the report; and a Place to make sugar: a Saginaw Chippewa land history, c. 1990, 455 p. The reference files include photocopies of Probate Court files, commonly referred to as "350 files" of Saginaw Chippewa Indians from the National Archives. These files are used to prove tribal genealogy, lineage, and membership. Each file usually includes: a letter to the Dept. of the Interior, Office of Indian Affairs re: approval of heirship, with the related Report on Heirship (form) and testimony of witnesses. A Status of (Land) Allotment (form) may be included. Many of the witnesses were illiterate and "signed" by leaving their mark, a fingerprint. Most of the files were processed through the Mount Pleasant (Mich.) Indian Agency, but others went through the Tomah Indian Agency in Green Bay (Wis.). User copies of the 350 files (1 cubic ft.) are available for patrons to use. Additional reference files document the Keweenaw Bay and L'Anse Native American communities in reports, correspondence, newspaper clippings, and other published materials.  A later addition of 16 boxes includes Keller's diaries, 1969-2010; Client Files, mostly 2005-2007, mostly documenting Saginaw Chippewa and other genealogical research; Caro historical materials;materialssdocumentingg Keller's parents; Native (American research) Files, mostly related to casinos and other, modern tribal issues and concerns, 2005-2007; Research Binders of mostly genealogical and Michigan Native American materials, and copies of Native American historical publications, 1992-2007. Correspodence in Box 26 is closed until 2030 as per donor agreement. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photograph Collection, 1916,1919.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection includes black and white photographs of: a group including Porterfield's mother, Helen Vowles, at the Isabella County Fair, 1917; a portrait of Helen Vowles, 1917; an unidentified kindergarten class at CMU in Mount Pleasant (Mich.), 1916; and individual and traveling photographs of the CMU Student Army Training Corps (CMUSATC), who traveled from Mt. Pleasant to Fort Custer in Battle Creek (Mich.) and then to Waco (Tex.) to be formed into the 32nd Infantry. The featured lieutenant may be Lt. Dancer who was in charge of CMUSATC in 1919. The photographs were identified by the donor, John Porterfield. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Pleasant to Fort Custer in Battle Creek (Mich.) and then to Waco (Tex.) to be formed into the 32nd Infantry. The featured lieutenant may be Lt. Dancer who was in charge of CMUSATC in 1919.                   <titleInfo>
                     <title>The Greeks scrapbook, 1940,1956.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Greeks scrapbook, 1940, 1950-1956, includes: photographs; newspaper and magazine articles; dance programs; notes; correspondence; Christmas cards; and miscellaneous documenting various fraternities and sororities at Central Michigan University (CMU). Photographs document the CMU homecoming parade floats of various fraternities and sororities and members of those organizations. The scrapbook pages are loose and extremely acidic and fragile. A broken wooden cover has been removed for preservation reasons. </abstract>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Organizational records, 1929-1963.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Organizational records, 1929-1963, include: a Ledger, 1942-1961, and Meeting Minutes, 1941-1961 (.5 cubic ft. in 1 box); Miscellaneous [reference materials], 1933-1963 (approximately .5 cubic ft. in 1 box); Sorority Files, which are reports on each sorority listing officers, members, and their annual events, as well as some supporting documentation (1 cubic ft. in 2 boxes); and Sorority Grade Point materials, which show the grade point average of each sorority sister and of each sorority, 1961-1964 (approximately .5 cubic ft. in 1 box). Also included is one folder each on the fraternity Delta Sigma Phi, 1948-1956, and Dr. D. Louise Sharp, which includes biographical material and photographs of Dr. Sharp. From documentation within the records it is clear that this was Dr. Sharp's collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1908,1968.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1908-ca. 1968 documents her life as a school teacher and principal. A 1932 graduate of Central Michigan Training School, now Central Michigan University (CMU), Webb worked as teacher and principal at Hillcrest schools in Alma (Mich.), 1942-1968. Included are newspaper clippings, awards, membership cards, CMU Alumni Association card, 1926, Oath of Allegiance card, 1939, and her [high school] matriculation card, 1926. There is a letter from P.G. Lantz, Superintendent of the Training School, CMU, and an attendance certificate from Morrison School District No. 2, Lakefield Township, Saginaw, June 1908. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>Papers, 1914-1975, undated. Most of the collection documents Shorts' business and insurance acumen, career, and interests. Oversized materials include: Certificates and Awards, 1942-1969; Photographs, 1906-1972 (scattered), undated; and Birthday Materials, 1958. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1900,1997.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1900-1970, 1996-1997, and undated, mostly from her years as a student at Central State Teachers Normal School (CSTS), now Central Michigan University (CMU). Her papers include notes; correspondence; class schedules; commencement programs for Bay County Normal, 1926, and CSTS, 1930, 1933, and 1935; class notes on Michigan education, 1853-1900; receipts for room, board, and tuition; report cards; teachers' contracts, 1927-1966 (scattered); related newspaper clippings, 1933-1961; her obituary, Jan. 1996; and a brochure of the Ruth M. M. Wesley Endowed Scholarship at CMU, 1997. Also included are three photographs of Ruth and friends at CMU, ca. 1925; a photograph of a house, undated; a photograph of Whither School, Bay City, ca. 1930s; a hymnal, undated; a Distinguished Service Award certificate from the Bay County Board of Education, undated; and a July 1, 1900 issue of The Intelligence : A Journal of Education. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:190823116</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University photograph of south campus showing "sheep sheds," ca. 1946?</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Black and white aerial photograph measuring 16 and 3/4 inches by 30 inches, glued onto a board, showing the railroad tracks, old powerhouse, "sheep sheds," dormitories, Warriner Hall, Finch Fieldhouse, the old football field, and other campus buildings from the southern end of Central Michigan University's campus. There are many big fields immediately north of campus in the photograph. The "sheep sheds" were buildings similar to barracks built after World War II to meet the sudden, increased need for student housing on campus. The buildings were supposed to be temporary structures, but the last was taken down in the 1980s. The "sheep sheds" functioned as student housing, classrooms, offices, and storage facilities. This is one of a few photographs actually showing the "sheep sheds." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:527883110</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>

                  <name>
                     <namePart>Rao, Michael S., 1967-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 2000-2009.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection is not composed of President Mike's official presidential papers. Rather, it was culled from newspapers, reports, updates, publications and university-wide emails. Some correspondence and reports in the collection are courtesy of now retired Professor Wayne Osborn, who served on high level university committees with President Mike. The collection documents President Mike's accomplishments and strategic vision, and public statements on topics such as diversity, the defeat of Proposal 2, racism, and school massacres, rather than his thought process or implementation plans. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, 1872,1969, includes record, books, and materials Ryan collected about dance in general, specific types of dance, and her life. Book topics include dance in general, folk, ballroom, children's, clog, square, modern, social, and tap dance, physical education, and songbooks. Biographical materials include photographs, her teaching notes, and information about Grace L. Ryan Hall, the part of Rose Center named for Ryan where dance classes are held at Central Michigan University. Disc record topics include dance in general, ballroom, folk, and square dancing. Biographies, a few photographic materials, and teaching notes of Ryan are also included. </abstract>

                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1913,1949. 1913</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers in the collection include: Johnson's birth certificate, 1913; letters of recommendation (5) November 1942, three of which are on letterhead from his associates at  the Indiana Farm Bureau Co-operative Association; and his divorce papers, October 1949. Photographs of Johnson in the collection include: his baby photograph, July 10, 1913; his high school graduation photograph [1931]; a photograph of him as a string bass player in a cowboy band, undated; World War II photographs of Johnson in naval uniform, two with family members, and one with a woman [perhaps his future wife?]; and a tinted photograph of his parents, ca. 1940s. Other photographs in the collection are of Torval Bersian, 1941, in his U.S. Navy uniform; Herman B. Harris in his U.S. army uniform, ca. 1940s; and an unidentified man, probably in the Pacific during World War II. Harris' dog tag is also included. These men were likely friends of Johnson. The photographs are of various sizes, and all but the tinted one are black and white. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Young Women's Christian Association Scrap Book, 1936,1992.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Young Women's Christian Association (YWCA) Scrap Book, 1936, 1945, includes: meeting programs, fliers, notes, and letters from YWCA members and advisers at Central Michigan University (CMU), as well as a thank you note, April 25, 1939, and a note about an upcoming event in Detroit, Sept. 23, 1936, from CMU President E.C. Warriner to Eddy. During June 19-27, 1936, Eddy and other YWCA members attended the YWCA Conference at Lake Geneva (Wis.). Eddy also attended the World Acquaintance Tour in Detroit on Oct. 24, 1936 with President Warriner and other students. Programs and materials for both events are included in the scrapbook. Also included are biographical materials (4 p., copies) on Eddy from the CMU Chippewa Yearbook, 1937, and CMU Alumni Directory, 1992. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

Warriner to Eddy. During June 19-27, 1936, Eddy and other YWCA members attended the YWCA Conference at Lake Geneva (Wis.). Eddy also attended the World Acquaintance Tour in Detroit on Oct. 24, 1936 with President Warriner and other students. Programs and materials for both events are included in the scrapbook. Also included are biographical materials (4 p., copies) on Eddy from the CMU Chippewa Yearbook, 1937, and CMU Alumni Directory, 1992.
resource.displayEntry: Eddy, Mary Ellen. Young Women's Christian Association Scrap Book, 1936,1992.

resourceRelations.content: Eddy, Mary Ellen. Young Women's Christian Association Scrap Book, 1936,1992.

                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Moore, Wilbur E.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Wilbur E. Moore Collection, 1942,1999.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes photographs, postcards, papers, and an obituary (copy) of Moore. Most of the collection consists of World War II photographs (59) in sizes varying from 8 x 10 to 2.5 x 2.5 inches. Some of the photographs have emulsions flaking off, but the majority of the images are These photographs document Moore in dress and work uniform, at Scott's Field, Belleville, Ill., in India, and in Fla. The images include other American servicemen, his unidentified girlfriend, natives of India, including musicians, camels, rickshaws, buildings, tents, a row of toilet holes and a row of tubs sitting on dirt without pipes. Some of the images include dates, 1942 or 1944-1945, but all are from this time period except for two more modern colored images, one of a street in India, 1999, and a color image of a map of Burma, undated. The papers include materials he wrote and researched or compiled on oil exploration of the Lower Tuscaloosa in Florida, Alabama, and Mississippi in 1958 and 1969. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Typed annual reports to the State Board of Education, 1927/28-1938/39; 1942/43-1945/46; 1948/49-1953/54; and 1955/56-1966/67. Included in the reports are statistical analysis of: students, degrees, classes, funds, buildings, faculty, salaries, enrollments, graduations, libraries, financial reports, grades, personnel services, activities, and public services. The reports were discontinued in 1967. Also included are similar reports, 1986/87-1993/94, from the CMU Alumni Office, which were created for public relations purposes. The alumni reports have been replaced by the Honor Roll of Donors reports. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:137273191</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Sharp, Virginia.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Photograph collection, 1915,1919.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Photograph collection of Central Michigan University (CMU) Student Army Training Corps (SATC) photographs, 1915, 1919 and undated. The black and white photographs (17) range in size from 2 1/4 x 3 1/4 inches to 8 x 10 inches. Included here are images of CMU buildings and members of the SATC, some in formal portrait and others in formal group photographs, mostly outside in winter coats. One group photograph is of a snowball fight and another is of men sitting inside a cafeteria. Other photographs are of training equipment for bayonet and trench warfare practice. The only identified men are Captain Vaugural and lieutenants Rider and Dancer. Several of the images are on postcards. One postcard is dated 1915 and was sent from Bill (no surname) to Clark Sharp in Vestaburg (Mich.). Two formal group photographs are stamped by the photographer: Collins, Mt. Pleasant, Mich. One has this additional information written on it in ink, "1919, the forgoten (sic) (Tin Soldiers) SATC Mt. Pleasant. There are some Local Boys here." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Photograph collection, 1915,1919.

The black and white photographs (17) range in size from 2 1/4 x 3 1/4 inches to 8 x 10 inches. One group photograph is of a snowball fight and another is of men sitting inside a cafeteria. Other photographs are of training equipment for bayonet and trench warfare practice. The only identified men are Captain Vaugural and lieutenants Rider and Dancer. Several of the images are on postcards.                      </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>President Judson W. Foust Papers, 1923,2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include Biographical Information, 1923,2002 (about .25 cubic ft.); Correspondence, 1935-1978 (about 1 cubic ft.); Meeting Minutes from Central Michigan University (CMU) entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1953-1968 (about 1.5 cubic ft.); Photographs, 1960-1968, undated (about .25 cubic ft.); Reports from CMU entities and educational related institutions and organizations, and the State Senate investigation reports of CMU, 1954-1968, undated (about 2.25 cubic ft.); and Subject Files, 1955-1968, undated, on a wide variety of topics relating to education, CMU, and numerous CMU departments (about 3.5 cubic ft.). Also included are six Scrapbooks, 1959-1967, and eleven Photograph Albums, 1958-1972 (2 cubic ft. total). Congratulatory letters on the occasion of Foust's inauguration as CMU's president on April 25, 1960 (about .5 cubic ft.), and his miscellaneous desk items, plaques, and awards are also included (2 cubic ft. total). Two oversized folders include awards, a certificate, congratulatory notes, a resolution, and letter of appreciation from the Korean Orphanage that CMU students supported. Information on the Korean Orphanage and Thailand Project, as well as Financial reports, 1959-1966, are also included in the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: President Judson W. Foust Papers, 1923,2002.
resource.abstract: Papers include Biographical Information, 1923,2002 (about .25 cubic ft.); Correspondence, 1935-1978 (about 1 cubic ft.); Meeting Minutes from Central Michigan University (CMU) entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1953-1968 (about 1.5 cubic ft.); Photographs, 1960-1968, undated (about .25 cubic ft.); Reports from CMU entities and educational related institutions and organizations, and the State Senate investigation reports of CMU, 1954-1968, undated (about 2.25 cubic ft.); and Subject Files, 1955-1968, undated, on a wide variety of topics relating to education, CMU, and numerous CMU departments (about 3.5 cubic ft.). Also included are six Scrapbooks, 1959-1967, and eleven Photograph Albums, 1958-1972 (2 cubic ft. total). Congratulatory letters on the occasion of Foust's inauguration as CMU's president on April 25, 1960 (about .5 cubic ft.), and his miscellaneous desk items, plaques, and awards are also included (2 cubic ft. total). Two oversized folders include awards, a certificate, congratulatory notes, a resolution, and letter of appreciation from the Korean Orphanage that CMU students supported. Information on the Korean Orphanage and Thailand Project, as well as Financial reports, 1959-1966, are also included in the collection.
resource.extent: 12 cubic ft. (in 13 boxes, 2 Oversized folders) : ill.
resource.displayEntry: Central Michigan University. Office of the President. President Judson W. Foust Papers, 1923,2002.

originationNames.name: Central Michigan University. Office of the President.

resourceRelations.content: Central Michigan University. Office of the President. President Judson W. Foust Papers, 1923,2002.

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:61126253</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Richtmeyer, Cleon C., 1903-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1938,1975.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1938, 1975, and undated, consist mainly of Instructors Semester Reports, 1949-1959, for instructors, professors, and departments at Central Michigan University (CMU). These reports give the name of the instructor, term, year, and the number of A, B, C, D, and E grades given to the students in each course, as well as the total grades for each course. These numbers and grades were compared statistically to those received at other colleges and universities accredited by the North Central Association of Colleges and Schools (NCACS). The purpose of the reports, and the correspondence and discussions they generated between CMU President Charles L. Anspach and the professors, was to guarantee that CMU would be accredited each time the NCACS evaluated it. Richtmeyer is personally documented by his obituary, April 8, 1975 (copy) and portrait photographs (copies from the CMU Photograph Faculty files), 1966 and undated. Reprints of three mathematics articles he wrote are also included in this collection. A copy of the book he co-wrote with Judson Foust, Business mathematics (1959) is also available at the Clarke. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Business records, 1892,1903.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Business records include: V. 1 Meeting Minutes, May 24, 1892-Aug. 11, 1903 with articles of association, by-laws, and meeting minutes. The erection of Central Michigan Normal School, later University, is noted on June 12, 1895. There are also newspaper clippings about bonds to be issued to build or expand the School. Pages 194-274 and 287-300 are blank. V. 2 Account book, 1893-1894 and undated, records property lots sold to the company with names of sellers, payments, and numbers of lots sold. Pages 54-87 are blank. Miscellaneous account lists are on the inside of the back cover. Fragments of miscellaneous papers are inside the front cover. Miscellaneous materials (in folder) include: a handwritten draft and a typed copy, 1892, of the articles of association; newspaper clippings (copies) about the sale of property for Central Michigan Normal School, later Central Michigan University (CMU), 1892; the record of votes on Senate Bill No. 7 (to establish a normal school in central Mich.), undated; a notice of the Mich. State Board of Education's support for the bill, 1895; drawings of property lots (with owners' names) that became the Normal School Addition, 1892-1893 (2 versions). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Architectural drawings for the renovation and addition to the Park Library include: a milestone schedule, concept drawings, site layout plans, an artist's renderings of interior and exterior views of the new building, and a vendor sample board of office furniture for staff, 1997-2001, by Greiner & Associates of Grand Rapids. Some of the drawings are mounted on foamcor board. The collection documents various stages of the planning prcess for the new building, as well as the furniture, shelving, signage, and electricity plans for it, and the landscaping and planting around it. </abstract>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:695595014</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Tuma, Clarence.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1961, 2009.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The Clarence Tuma Papers, 1961, 2009, and undated, consist of the Tuma family genealogical materials, newspaper clippings, magazine articles, speeches, recipes, menus, bank statements and awards and certificates. The topically grouped material is arranged alphabetically. Newspaper clippings, 1960-2007, include information on Tuma's World War II Service, The Embers, and the Rashid Family. Photographs consist of Tuma's service in World War II, family, The Embers, and Rashid Family Reunions. A special note is to be given to three photographs in the collection of a funeral of an unidentified individual. Also included are awards and certificates, 1964-2007, and plaques comprising of the Trustee Appreciation Award, the Salut Au Restaurateur Award, and the Alumni Recognition Award. Oversize Folder 1 contains oversized documents such as bank statements and certificates. Oversize Folder 2 contains family photos. Oversize Folder 3 contains a photograph of the Embers Restaurant in Traverse City, Michigan. Oversize Folder 4 contains photos of the Rashid Club of America. Electronic sources include DVDs of Clarence Tuma's 80th Birthday, the 75th Reunion of the Rashid Club of America and the Lion's Club Farewell to the Embers. A cassette tape is also included, which is titled "Congratulations Clarence and Janet Tuma." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <namePart>Sugars, Rachel.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Mt. Pleasant, 1920.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Handwritten report [18 p.], ca. 1920?, about Mount Pleasant (Mich.) with maps, postcards, some colored, of Central Michigan University (CMU) and Mount Pleasant buildings, including: Borden's Milk Factory, Harris Milling Co., Columbia Sugar Co., the Post Office, the U.S. Indian School, . and Broadway at Normal (now University) Ave. The covers are made from construction paper. The front cover has a design of art deco-style lotus flowers and "Mt. Pleasant" pasted onto the cover in blue paper. The report is attached with a blue cord. A note on page 2 reads "This book was sent to me July 1964 by Golden Coleman of 322 N. Williams, Ludington, Mich. She was not sure of the date. It was a thesis by a Normal Student of long ago-a Rachel Sugars. You can see by the pictures that it is old. Very interesting. Mrs. Frank (Laura A.) Robinson." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:56088036</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Hooks, Bell.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1992.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection includes a cassette tape of Bell Hooks speaking at Warriner Auditorium at Central Michigan University (CMU) on Sept. 16, 1992, and answering questions after her speech entitled "Revolution of values: ending domination". In her speech, Hooks talks about her first integrated high school reunion, which caused her to remember being forced to integrate into a white school, the problems and issues that were involved in the process, and her friendship with a white boy and his family. She decries capitalism, fear in our culture, racism and materialism. Also in her speech, Hooks quotes the Rev. Martin Luther King, Jr., whom she respects, and Alice Walker, whom she does not. Also included in the collection is a newspaper article about the speech from CMLife (2 pp.), and biographical information on Hooks from the internet (2 pp.). CMU libraries have many of her books. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Family papers, 1901,1944.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Family papers, 1901-1944 and undated, include biographical materials; correspondence; diplomas (mostly from Central State Normal School, now Central Michigan University), 1901, 1903, 1905, 1907, 1914; notebooks; photographic materials; and miscellaneous. Papers include those of Mary, her sisters, Anna L. and Julia L., and their parents Louis and Mary L. Bourgeois of Union Township and Mount Pleasant (Mich.). Of special note are two photograph albums of Mary's nursing experience before and during her stay in France during World War I, 1918-1919. One of the albums entitled A.E.F. (American Expeditionary Force) is a gorgeous piece of art and includes images of soldiers, patients, graves, French people, parades, religious events, buildings, famous cities, sites devastated by bombs, and tourist sites, as well as the ships she sailed on her way to France and home to the U.S. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:49061315</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>

                     <namePart>Ryder, Walter S. (Walter Scott)</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1909-1956.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes: Biographical Information, mainly in newspaper clippings (copies); his Cashbooks, 1931-1944; Diaries, 1909-1956; Photographs and Postcards made of photographs; Sermons, 1910-1919; Writings, 1933 and undated; and church-related miscellaneous. The diaries document his years at Acadia University, 1910-1915, in great detail. Other diaries vary in the amount of detail and document his serving as minister of Havelock Baptist Church, 1915-1916, and living in Parma (N.Y.), 1916-1921; Vancouver, 1919; Chicago and Savanna (Ill.), 1919-1924; Oshkosh (Wis.), 1925-1927; St. Paul (Minn.), 1928-1934, Flint (Mich.), 1935-1942, and Mount Pleasant (Mich.), 1942-1956. His correspondence file is mainly brief notes from Central Michigan University (CMU)'s Pres. Charles L. Anspach or CMU Business Manager Norval C. Bovee. The index of his sermons includes a list of baptisms, marriages, and funerals he performed, 1919-1921. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:41000083</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Wood, Anna Stanley Schofield, 1884-1983.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1888,1954.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include the correspondence of Annie (Anna) Stanley, while a student at the Michigan Normal School, now Central Michigan University (CMU). The correspondence of Sept. 21, 1899, Sept. 27, 1899, and Nov. 15, 1899 to "Dear Mama and Jim," to "Dear brother" on Oct. 13, 1899, and "Dear Uncle Dan [McSweyn]" on March 3, 1900, describes college life, homesickness, friends, and her professors, in Annie's handwriting in pencil. Also, there is a letter, written in ink, from a train conductor to Anna's mother, Jane McSweyn, before she married Richard S. Stanley, giving traveling directions by train from Toronto (Ontario, Canada) to Saginaw (Mich.), dated Jan. 20, 1888. Some of these letters are extremely acidic. Also included are (copies of) Anna's third grade teacher's certificate, 1906, and a newspaper article about her being the oldest student on the CMU campus in 1954 at the age of 70 with a note to her from Stephen P. Nisbet. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <namePart>Central Michigan University. Office of the President.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Warriner, Eugene Clarence.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>President Eugene C. Warriner Papers, 1882,2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes Dr. Warriner's personal papers, 1885, 2002, including Biographical Information, with a Scrapbook, undated, ca. 1890; Diaries and Date Books, 1885,1937; his license to Preach, 1913; Photographs, undated; and related newspaper articles (copies). Other series include Correspondence, with a few folders of personal correspondence, 1902-1940, undated; Meeting Minutes of various Central Michigan University (CMU) organizations and committees, 1932-1940; Reports of CMU and educational organizations, 1919,1939; Speeches Dr. Warriner gave, 1906-1942, undated; Subject Files, 1896-1948, including CMU football scores, 1896-1939, and two student papers about Dr. Warriner, 1952, undated; Dr. Warriner's Writings, 1900-1935, undated; and 3"x5" index cards, indexing his correspondence, 1882-1939, undated (2 small boxes). The collection provides good documentation on Warriner, his interests, such as Prohibition and Temperance, ideas, and education and CMU related issues of interest during his tenure as CMU's president, such as Women's Suffrage and football. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:75956254</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kalencki, Myrtle.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 2006.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include Mrs. Kalencki's handwritten notes about various aspects of her life attending and teaching in rural schools. The collection includes: a history of Schofield School in Gilmore Township (Isabella County, Mich.), 9 pp.; a history of Gilmore Center (Isabella County, Mich.) ca. 1920, 3 pp.; a history of her experiences teaching in Gulick, Herring, and Walton schools beginning in 1936, 22 pp.; and "Some Random Thoughts", 4pp., mostly about teaching, getting coal, being responsible for keeping the schools warm and clean, and her experiences boarding with various people. Her histories are quite interesting documenting the challenges the teacher faced, support received, financial situations, regulations, subjects students studied, books they read for fun, and games they played, some of which she learned from Professor Grace Ryan at Central Michigan University (CMU). Kalencki notes that in Walton School she had children from three Chippewa Indian families as pupils, and that she received lovely baskets woven by the Neyome family. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Posters collection, 1968,2006.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection of 563 posters, 1968, 2006 [bulk 1980-2006], and undated, created and/or collected by Central Michigan University Public Relations and Marketing. The posters promote a wide variety of CMU events, departments, offices, speakers, workshops, conferences, as well as some non-university community events, including theater, and miscellaneous topics of interest ot the CMU community. The size, color, and composition of the posters vary greatly, as do the designs, which range from enlarged photographs of university buildings to very artistically designed theatrical posters. The vast majority of the posters are undated. Folders are organized alphabetically by topic. Posters are chronologically filed within folders. CMU poster topics include: Admissions; CMU and You Day; Art Festivals; Art Gallery; Artists Course; Athletics; Beaver Island (Biological Station); Career Day; Charles Anspach Platform Series (speakers); Conferences; Departments; Development Fund/ Campus Campaigns; Faculty Conferences/ Programs; Film Festivals; Foreign Language Day; Graduate Studies/ Extended Degree Programs; Greater Michigan Instructional Materials Exhibits; Greeks/ Fraternities/ Sororities; Health Services; IPCD (Institute for Personal and Career Development); Library; Minority Affaris; Museum; Musical Performances; Office of Career Development of Handicapped Persons; Other Speakers Sponsored by CMU; Percussion Workshops; Program Board/ Speaker Series; Racism; Scholarship; the School of Music; Sexual Assault/ Harassment; Student Art Exhibits; Student Services; Study Abroad; Summer Classes/ Programs; Theater. Non-CMU poster topics include: Community Events, Energy/ Conservation; Miscellaneous; and Theater. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:44522492</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Central Michigan University.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>75th Anniversary Collection, 1893-1972.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection, 1893-1972 and undated, consists of correspondence, meetings minutes and agendas of the Central Michigan University (CMU) 75th Anniversary Advisory Committe and 75th Anniversary Awards Screening Committee, as well as materials they generated, including: faculty announcements, historical marker materials, historical sketches of CMU, newspaper articles, publications, and souvenirs. The committees also sponsored a history of CMU compiled by Dr. Rolland H. Maybee. His reference materials, text, photographs, note cards, drafts of various chapters, and recordings compose the majority of the collection. Some papers of John DeCarlos, Vice-president, Public Services; Wilbur E. Moore, Vice-president, Academic Affairs; William B. Boyd, President of CMU; and Michigan Senator Robert P. Griffin are also found in the collection. Correspondence with and biographical materials about Roger Allen, architect of many of CMU's buildingsare also included. Allen was one of the honorees of the anniversary celebration. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Personnel files, 1926-1977.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Personnel Files of Central Michigan University faculty and staff who died, retired, or otherwise separated from the university at least thirty years ago. All social security numbers, health, and personal information has been removed. Each Personnel File may include: appointment letters/contracts; approvals/denials relating to personnel matters, reappointment/promotion/tenure, sabbatical/leave records, salary notices, reduced assignments; commendations (CMU related); curriculum vitae (resume); disciplinary documentation; personnel transaction forms; and transcripts; clippings (copies), obituary notices, or photographs. The files are filed alphabetically by surname within each group of retires based on the year of their retirement or separation from the university. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection includes two items: a warped, vellum Central State Normal School three years teaching certificate, with gold seal and an image of the state seal, signed and dated August 5, 1910; and a late 20th century copy of an earlier photograph of Inez Field seated on top of a student desk in one of the first school she taught at, either Rose City or Standish, Michigan, with two students, desks, a stove, and vivid wallpaper visible behind her, circa 1912-1913. The photograph is identified on the back in black ink. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:55879446</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Champion wrestling matches, [1921],2000.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Broadside (copy) advertising Champion wrestling matches, [under the] auspices of [the] American Legion, Friday, Evening, March 4th [undated, but probably in 1921], [at the] Shepherd Opera House, Pete Mitropolous, [the] World's Champion vs. Young Baker, Champion of the Southwest. The broadside has photographs of Mitropolous, wearing a World War I uniform with medals, and a bare-chested Baker. Also scheduled to wrestle were Hollis Fickle, Champion of Isabella County [Mich.] and Nelson Hillock, Champion of Gratiot County. The cost of admission was one dollar and ten cents (ringside), 83 cents (general), and 55 cents (ladies and children). Hillock's obituary (copy), 2000, is also included. [Note: This broadside probably dates from 1921. There are only three years in the early 20th century when a March 4th is a Friday: 1904 when Hollis would have been a year old; 1910, when Hollis was seven-years-old; and 1921, shortly after World War I when men were still wearing their uniforms to demonstrate their service record and appeal to people's patriotism.]. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The broadside has photographs of Mitropolous, wearing a World War I uniform with medals, and a bare-chested Baker. Also scheduled to wrestle were Hollis Fickle, Champion of Isabella County [Mich.] and Nelson Hillock, Champion of Gratiot County. The cost of admission was one dollar and ten cents (ringside), 83 cents (general), and 55 cents (ladies and children). Hillock's obituary (copy), 2000, is also included. [Note: This broadside probably dates from 1921. There are only three years in the early 20th century when a March 4th is a Friday: 1904 when Hollis would have been a year old; 1910, when Hollis was seven-years-old; and 1921, shortly after World War I when men were still wearing their uniforms to demonstrate their service record and appeal to people's patriotism.].
