                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, includes Meeting Minutes and Proposals, 1970-1972, of the Central Michigan University (CMU) Indian Education Project Ad Hoc Committee (1 folder). Also incuded are materials documenting the CMU Vietnam Moratorium, including: a brochure that accompanied the film documentary of the Moratorium, 1969; original photographs, some of which were used in the brochure and are partially identified by Prof. Littlefield's notes, 1969; and copies of memorandums sent between CMU Pres. William B. Boyd, CMU Vice Pres. for Student Affairs Al Miles, and the CMU Faculty Advisory Council about CMU student protest actions of April 19-21, 1971, such as starting fires on CMU land, sleeping on the lawn, and other general protest actions. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <title>Papers, 1970-1999.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1970-1999, undated include his research, writing, and related correspondence. Most of the collection consists of Dawson's research, photographs, drafts of manuscripts, and correspondence about republishing Della T. Lutes' Country Kitchen cookbook and publishing an article about Billy Clark, a Michigan minstrel. There is also a typed, 45-page paper with a variety of U.S. Centennial poetry from Michigan newspapers, compiled by Dawson. (The Clarke Historical Library has the Lutes papers and three scrapbooks about Billy Clark and minstrel shows.). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <abstract>Typed, 10 p. history by Welch and Johnson about the history and development of kindergarten in Mount Pleasant, Mich, from 1887 to 1937, including private kindergartens, kindergartens at Central State Teachers College (CSTC), the Helen R. Emmons Club at CSTC, kindergartens in the public schools, and a very brief paragraph on Catholic kindergarten. The last date discussed in this undated paper is 1937.                   <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>

                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>

<objectXMLWrap>

                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:39650043</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke, Norman Ellsworth, 1892-1984.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1889,1998.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, 1889,1998 and undated, includes Clarke's certificates of appreciation; degrees earned; correspondence; materials related to his collecting interests; articles he wrote; and a draft of his autobiography. His memorabilia includes: a Masonic fez, fez bag, apron, and pins; as well as plaques; an academic hood; and drawings of the Civil War steamer Diana. A collection of publications on the heart, endate, chelation therapy, and ethylene diamino tetraacetic acid (E.D.T.A.), reflecting his research and professional interests are also included. There are also some audio visual materials, mostly cassette tapes, of research topics of interest to Dr. Clarke, and a tape of an award dinner when he was honored for his service to Providence Hospital. Photographs and other visual or illustrative materials are found throughout the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:39708011</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>De Bolt, Joe.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University Vietnam Moratorium Committee Records, 1967,1983.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Records, 1967-1971, 1983, and undated include an Oversized reel of an 8-mm film "Moratorium" by De Bolt with shots of a gathering of 4,000 protestors at Finch Fieldhouse, at Central Michigan University (CMU), and 5,000 people marching through the streets of Mount Pleasant (Mich.), both on Oct. 15, 1969, a Nov. 14, 1969 memorial service, teach-in at Ferris State College, a rally at Finch Fieldhouse with 500 people, and loading buses for marches in Washington, D.C., on Nov. 15,1969. The film has an accompanying pamphlet. Also included are Committee accounts, meeting minutes, a petition, speeches, and newsletters. Underground newspapers and literature from other colleges related to anti-war efforts, radicalism, or pro-labor groups are included. Also included is a modern VHS video of the film. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

The film has an accompanying pamphlet. Also included are Committee accounts, meeting minutes, a petition, speeches, and newsletters.                   </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Warriner Hall grounds photograph album, 1950,1956.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Small photograph album with orange cover with "Van's super-album quality prints, Michigan's finest photo finishing" on the cover. Inscribed on the inside front cover is "Taken 1955-1956.". The album includes ten black and white images, each measuring 3"x4.5", of snow covered trees and blooming magnolia trees in spring. Several of the snowy images are identified as views from the circulation room in Warriner Hall, circa 1950, at Central Michigan University. Other images appear to be taken in someone's backyard and are dated 1955 or 1956. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1938, 1984.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include 1 p. (copy) from the Central Michigan University Chippewa Yearbook 1915 with an image of Arbuckle; 1 p. (copy) of her obituary, 1984; 123 pp. mostly handwritten, in ink, teaching stories and scenarios for a health education extension course written by Arbuckle while teaching in Clarion (Mich.). The stories include some dittos and attachments, and a 1 p. letter, printed in pencil, to the School Board asking permission to plant a flower garden by Ronnie [no surname], in second grade. Topics of Arbuckle's stories include good teeth, a mental case, cloakroom problems, food in general, the school environment, foods from the Detroit Dairy and Food Council, a community study, amounts of food, 4-H lunch, a study of a child, and a summary of the year's accomplishments. Critiques and notes in another hand, handwritten in pencil, are found on some of her stories. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1945-1946.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, 1945-1946, undated, includes correspondence from Milles, Cranbrook Academy of Art, to Frances G. Fitch, Central State Teachers College (CSTC), Mount Pleasant (Mich.), inviting her to visit, Nov. 17, 1945, and wishing her a speedy recovery of health, June 5, 1946. Also included are a catalog of Milles work for the J.L. Hudson Gallery exhibit, Detroit, Jan. 14-Feb. 6, 1940 , and a booklet autographed by Milles on the occassion of his 70th birthday, June 23, 1945. Both the catalog and booklet are illustrated. A resolution of respect to Prof. Fitch for 19 years of service from CSTC, Aug. 15, 1957, completes the collection. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:707536567</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University oversized images, 1968, 1969.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Miscellaneous collection of Central Michigan University images include, in 1 oversized folder: sepia-tone image of north view of Warriner Hall in fall, pasted to black mat, measures 20 x 24 inches, 1969, signature of photographer Paul B----; two modern reproductions of images from the Clarke's collection, stamped as such on back, 1) an unidentified, early commencement image, circa 1890s, of five women and a man, dressed up with flowers and diplomas on the floor, measures 15 x 19 inches; 2) 1896 freshman class of fourteen women and four men dressed up, measures 15 x 19.5 inches, and has sustained some sun damage. Also included is a framed, color photograph of President Foust. There is some damage on the lower third of the image from the frame and scrapping. The frame is painted gold, it measures 20x 24 inches, is 2.5 inches thick and does not include glass. The plaque on the frame reads, "Judson W. Foust, Ph.D., Professor of Mathematics, 1929-1932, Vice President, 1952-1959, President 1959-1968, Central Michigan University." </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1919, 2007, and undated, include: Biographical Materials with Central Michigan College Education Guide Book for Educational Development, 1944-1955; Michigan Education Association Retired Ceritificate of Life Membership, 1983; Central Michigan College of Education 57th Commencement Program, 1952; Photograph of Gladwin High School Graduation Class of 1931; eleven miscellaneous family photographs (scanned copies), 1919, 1932, 1961, and undated. Also included are her Diaries, 1934-1991 (Scattered, 9 v.) a travel jouunral, 1952-1997 (Scattered), and her hymnal and Holy Bible. The diaries are a record of the weather, her activities, and notes about family and friends. They are not reflective, emotional, or cerebral in nature. There is no mention of world events. </abstract>

Boyd's inauguration, 1968; the University Center Construction, 1951, and Dormitory shots, 1951. The collection is housed on metal reels in metal cannisters and has a vinegar smell, indicating some decomposition of the safety film. </abstract>

                     <role>

One national convention program is from Biloxi (Miss.), 1955. The original wooden covers were removed as they were contributing to the decomposition of the pages of the scrapbook. The scrapbook pages are loose, extremely acidic and fragile. The scrapbook should be used with extreme care by researchers. </abstract>

                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>President Harold Abel Papers, 1964,2002.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers include Biographical Information, 1975,1985, undated (3 folders); Correspondence, 1972-1985 (approx. .5 cubic ft.); Meeting Minutes from Central Michigan University (CMU) entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1964,1985 (approx. .5 cubic ft. total); Photographs, 1981, undated (a few folders); Reports from CMU entities and educational related institutions and organizations, 1964,1985 (approx. .5 cubic ft.); Speeches, 1976, 1985 (9 folders); and most of the rest of the collection consists of Subject Files, 1973-1987, on a wide variety of topics relating to education, CMU, and numerous CMU departments and entities. There is also one Plaque, to Pres. Abel in appreciation from the Korean Amateur Sports Assn., 1977. An Oversized Michigan Senate Resolutio No. 691, re: CMU, July 2, 1890, completes the collection. The collection includes lots of financial, budget, fundraising, and Development Fund information. Other topics documented at length in the collection include the CMU. Institute for Personal and Career Development (IPCD), commencements, the Jane Fonda Controversy, and Korean universities of Chung Ang and Hanyang. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Family papers, 1909,1974.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Family papers, 1909, 1974 include diplomas, certificates, obituaries (copies) of Edward J. and Jessie I. (McGee) Grambau, as well as miscellaneous papers regarding their World War II work as Isabella County (Mich.) chairs of the Fat Salvage project (Jessie) and Victory Garden project (Edward). Jessie's papers include her Lake City High School diploma, May 27, 1915; Missaukee County Normal School Training Class diploma, May 26, 1919; Central Michigan Normal School, later Central Michigan University (CMU) diploma and art diploma, both dated June 21, 1921; and Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) membership certificate, Aug. 10, 1922 (stained). Her World War II miscellaneous papers include a blood bank receipt, 1943; Red Cross certificate, 1942; Red Cross report and note, 1940s; and a Citizens Defense Air Raid Warden certificate with related card and letter, 1943. Her Fat Salvage project materials include a list of Mich. county chairs, 1940s; Bulletins #73 and 79, 1942; a letter and three promotional sheets, 1940s; and newspaper clippings (copies, 2 p.), 1943, 1940s. Edward's papers include his diploma (with gold seal and blue ribbon) from Michigan Common School, May 11, 1909; and from Michigan Agricultural College, later Michigan State University (MSU), his seminarium botanicum certificate, May 11, 1920; College Life certificate (with gold seal), Dec. 29, 1920; and B.S. degree (vellum with gold seal), Jan. 19, 1921. His World War II materials include a sugar purchase certificate, 1944; ration book with stamps, 1942; two, undated certificates of appreciation for his efforts with the U.S. Treasury's war financing program and Victory Garden project; an Isabella County Defense Council out-door patriotic rally agenda, 1940s (4 p.); and newspaper clippings (copies, 3 p.), 1940s. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Senate resolution No. 691, 1980.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Senate resolution No. 691, a resolution of tribute to the leadership of Central Michigan University (CMU), offered by Senators Faust, Plawecki, Corbin, Welborn and Arthurhultz, on July 4, 1980. The administration of CMU voluntarily went without their pay raises for 1981-1982, helping the state during a time of economic and financial hardship. The resolution has the signature stamp of William C. Kandler, Secretary of the Senate. The resolution includes the state seal and the face of a woman in illustrative scrolling in red ink around the text, which is in red and black ink, on white paper. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:630153404</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Enberg, Dick.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1935-2009</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes papers, photographs, and artifacts, which are organized by format, size, title, and chronologically. Except for some of his photographs, Baby Book, and a student paper, all of the other materials in the collection were generated by his career. Among these are correspondence, photographs, awards, essays, play-by-play statistics and notes, broadcast related notes and statistics. Artifacts in the collection include: pins and identity cards, a plaque, a baseball, a towel, and a blazer. Particularly unusual to other manuscript collections are his oversized Basketball Broadcast Boards, 1992-1994, and undated, and Football Broadcast Boards, 1980-1996, and undated. These contain a wealth of information about the players' personal and professional lives and dreams, and other broadcast related notes and essays, demonstrating his vast accumulation and knowledge of the athletes and sports. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Central Michigan University cross-country uniform, ca. 1930s.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Central Michigan University (CMU) cross-country uniform, worn by Neil Hoover, during the 1930s. The uniform includes a white, cotton tank top with white linen shorts. The tank top has a [homemade?] pink, felt heraldic badge with a black, felt arrow and black, felt letter "C" on it. The shorts have a black vertical stripe on the side of each leg, two white buttons in the front (a third button is missing), and a string tie (belt) in the back. Both the tank and shorts are stained and faded. There are no labels on the clothing. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:610974816</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Kjolhede, Virginia.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1912,2008.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection is divided into two series, each in its own box: first the materials of Ted Kjolhede, and second, the materials of Marion Kraft Larson. Series (Box) 1 consists of materials documenting the life of Ted Kjolhede, including biographical materials, photographs of his athletic career and teams, articles and letters to the editors he wrote, many of which were published in the Morning Sun, and various materials related to Central Michigan University (CMU) athletics, CMU World War II graduates, and his career at CMU. Series (Box) 2  consists mostly of newspaper and magazine articles (copies) collected or created by Marion Kraft Larson about her high school classmate Ernest Hemingway. Also included are a few biographical materials about Marion. Of particular interest, is her Memory Book of Oak Park and River Forest Township High School, 1917, signed by Ernest and Marcelline Hemingway, among others, and her 1972 paper about her memories of Ernest Hemingway and his family, entitled "Yes, I Knew Ernest Hemingway." There is one undated, color photograph of Marion, and a photograph album, 1912-1913, probably of her primary school mates. Also included is one oversized photograph of the Oak Park and River Forest Township High School graduation class, 1917. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

Also included are a few biographical materials about Marion. Of particular interest, is her Memory Book of Oak Park and River Forest Township High School, 1917, signed by Ernest and Marcelline Hemingway, among others, and her 1972 paper about her memories of Ernest Hemingway and his family, entitled "Yes, I Knew Ernest Hemingway." There is one undated, color photograph of Marion, and a photograph album, 1912-1913, probably of her primary school mates. Also included is one oversized photograph of the Oak Park and River Forest Township High School graduation class, 1917.
resource.displayEntry: Kjolhede, Virginia. Collection, 1912,2008.

resourceRelations.content: Kjolhede, Virginia. Collection, 1912,2008.

                  <name>
                     <namePart>Weideman, Christine, 1893-1895.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>CMNS Times photograph album, 1893-1895.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Small photograph album of thirty-five images placed into black corner holders. One image is missing. Images range from approximately 2"x3" to 3"x4.5" in size. Two portraits have been cut out of the original images so there is no background. Images, mostly identified, include portraits of several professors, male and female student friends at home, on excursions near the Chippewa River, and on campus, with bicycles, and the effects of a terrible ice storm that hit campus. There are a lot of images of female students being goofy in costumes, pulling each others hair, and lying around in bed. Christine Weideman's name is on the inside front cover. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:61257239</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Minor, Van Lieu.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1907,1946.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The majority of the collection, 1907, 1946, and undated, documents the academic career of Minor at University High School, Chicago (Ill.), 1907, 1912-1917, and 1921-1922; Kalamazoo Central High School, Kalamazoo (Mich.), 1921-1924; and Central Michigan University (CMU), 1924-1946. The high school materials are mainly tests and some syllabi for the many classes he taught, and a few pieces of correspondence. The CMU academic materials include: tests for many CMU courses;  meeting minutes and related materials of the CMU. Curriculum Committee; CMU. departments of History and Social Sciences correspondence; correspondence to Professor Claude S. Larzelere; and meeting minutes of various committees. Also included are the lists of members, constitutions, and related correspondence, 1927-1942, of the CMU. Cliophiles Club, a student history organization, and a 1945 student research paper on Ora Labora, a German communal settlement which existed in Huron County (Mich.) from 1862 to 1871. Of particular interest are the correspondence, notes, and related materials documenting the League of Nations Association assemblies, 1929-1935 and 1939, as well as Bureau of Naturalization Educational Record Cards, 1916-1924, for twelve immigrant men who took night courses from Professor Minor while he taught in Kalamazoo.  Personal Materials in the collection include: Biographical Information on Minor and his family, 1924, 1927, 1934 (copies); a few Publications that Minor wrote; Correspondence with the Boys Brotherhood Republic in Chicago, a reform organization for juvenile delinquents, 1914 and 1916; and budgets for the Minor family, 1921 and 1923. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1907,1946.

The high school materials are mainly tests and some syllabi for the many classes he taught, and a few pieces of correspondence. The CMU academic materials include: tests for many CMU courses;  meeting minutes and related materials of the CMU. <objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:52042777</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Beach, Margaret E.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Collection, 1909, 1922.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Collection, 1909, 1922, undated, includes: black and white photographs, postcards, diplomas, and biographical information (copies) from Central State Normal School, later Central Michigan University (CMU), Yearbooks of Leo S. Beach, 1919 and 1922. The collection is organized by type of material and size. Among the 17 photographs is one of Vice President Coolidge, several images of Bay City (Mich.), CMU ROTC, 1920, several images of unidentified office staff, 1909 and undated, a photograph of what may be the Houghton Lake pavilion, another of the Copper Range Yards in Houghton (Mich.), a rolled photograph of CMU graduates in June 1920, and photographs of various buildings and unidentified people. Diplomas are for Leo S. Beach from CMU, for a B.A. (1922), and for a life teaching certificate (1919), and a diploma for Ethel Louise Ames from Castern High School, Saginaw (Mich.), 1913. The postcard souvenir booklet of CMU buildings is ca. 1920s. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Summer Sessions Reports to the President, 1942-1960.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Summer Sessions Reports to the President of Central Michigan University (CMU), 1942-1960. Statistical reports of numbers and types of students, courses, course loads of professors, etc. Reports were generated by Judson W. Foust, in his capacity as Director of Summer Sessions, for CMU President Charles L. Anspach. The cover of each report has a picture from the corresponding CMU course schedule of the same year. There is no extant report for 1959, but there is a folder of the statistics used to compile the report. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:781111864</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:OCLC-EHL</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Maybee, Rolland Harper, 1901-</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1835, 1970.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Papers, 1835, 1970, and undated include: biographical information, manuscripts, research and notes, and correspondence (including Central Michigan University (CMU) Department of Social Sciences, Michigan Historical Society, personal, and student academics). Box 2 includes correspondence with President Dwight D. Eisenhower and correspondence between H.L. Menckin and Mr. Leighly. Telegrams from the following people can be found in Box 8: Richard Nixon, Congressman Elford A. Cederberg, Governor G. Mennen Williams, and Arthur S. Flemming (Secretary of the Department of Health, Education, and Welfare). Box 4 includes a letter from Henry Miller, and Box 6 has newspaper clippings (copies) related to Senator Robert Griffin, and alum of  CMU. Also included are papers, correspondence, diplomas and certificates from / of CMU Professor Claude S. Larzelere (2 boxes, 1 Oversized folder). </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Clarke Historical Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
